urn:contentItem:5RF6-H5B1-JCBF-S0P7-00000-00SEN. MORAN ON CNBC'S SQUAWK BOX: "WE NEED TO GET OUT OF THE CR BUSINESS"2018-01-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:22ZLexisNexisSEN. MORAN ON CNBC'S SQUAWK BOX: "WE NEED TO GET OUT OF THE CR BUSINESS"States News ServiceWASHINGTON

The following information was released by Kansas Senator Jerry Moran:

U.S. Senator Jerry Moran (R-Kan.) this morning joined CNBCs Squawk Box to discuss his support for returning to the full Appropriations process in order to prioritize spending, rather than relying on short-term continuing resolutions (CRs) to fund the government. He also discussed this mornings Senate Commerce Committee hearing entitled, Terrorism and Social Media: Is Big Tech Doing Enough? and his return to the Senate Banking Committee, which today voted in support of Jay Powell to chair the Federal Reserve Board of Governors.

Joe Kernen (3:40): Both sides use immigration as sort of a political football to highlight worries about terrorism, the people that want to end chain migration and lotteries, they say that, I dont know, most of the incidents that have happened have been perpetrated by individuals that got here that way. Others say not so. Whats the right middle ground there, how do we solve, where do you think were going to go? Will the government stay open?

Sen. Moran (4:19): We ought to have a continuing resolution, not shut down government, but we ought to do it for a very short period of time a day or two and stay here and resolve these differences. Because not only are we talking about DACA and immigration, the attempt to resolve those issues which are very important, but also disaster assistance, the list is long CHIP, the program for healthcare, the Collins-Nelson bill. We ought not delay these things until March. Im a member of the Appropriations Committee as well and I dont want us to be back here in February with another continuing resolution. We need to get out of the CR business and get to doing 12 appropriations bills. This is where we can prioritize spending, we can reduce spending, and perhaps most importantly we can rein in agencies, departments and bureaucrats with directions about how the money can be spent.

Sen. Moran (5:14): Congress every once in a while, we get some credit these days and its perhaps one of our greater successes reining in regulations. Weve done that via CRA, a congressional process by which you can reject administration regulations, and we can only do that in a very narrow path. Where we can do that every year, every day is in appropriations by taking away money that comes from bad behavior or bad ideas. We need to get out of the CR and get into an appropriations process again.

urn:contentItem:5RF8-4N31-DYVR-P42M-00000-00Sen. Moran on CNBC's Squawk Box: "We Need to Get Out of the CR Business";Sen. Moran, Jerry - (R - KS) News Release2018-01-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:22ZLexisNexisU.S. SENATE DOCUMENTSSen. Moran on CNBC's Squawk Box: "We Need to Get Out of the CR Business"Sen. Moran, Jerry - (R - KS) News Release

WASHINGTON - U.S. Senator Jerry Moran (R-Kan.) this morning joined CNBC's Squawk Box to discuss his support for returning to the full Appropriations process in order to prioritize spending, rather than relying on short-term continuing resolutions (CRs) to fund the government. He also discussed this morning's Senate Commerce Committee hearing entitled, "Terrorism and Social Media: Is Big Tech Doing Enough?" and his return to the Senate Banking Committee, which today voted in support of Jay Powell to chair the Federal Reserve Board of Governors.

Joe Kernen (3:40): "Both sides use immigration as sort of a political football to highlight worries about terrorism, the people that want to end chain migration and lotteries, they say that, I don't know, most of the incidents that have happened have been perpetrated by individuals that got here that way. Others say 'not so.' What's the right middle ground there, how do we solve, where do you think we're going to go? Will the government stay open?"

Sen. Moran (4:19): "We ought to have a continuing resolution, not shut down government, but we ought to do it for a very short period of time - a day or two - and stay here and resolve these differences. Because not only are we talking about DACA and immigration, the attempt to resolve those issues which are very important, but also disaster assistance, the list is long... CHIP, the program for healthcare, the Collins-Nelson bill. We ought not delay these things until March. I'm a member of the Appropriations Committee as well and I don't want us to be back here in February with another continuing resolution. We need to get out of the CR business and get to doing 12 appropriations bills. This is where we can prioritize spending, we can reduce spending, and perhaps most importantly we can rein in agencies, departments and bureaucrats with directions about how the money can be spent."

Sen. Moran (5:14): "Congress every once in a while, we get some credit these days and it's perhaps one of our greater successes - reining in regulations. We've done that via CRA, a congressional process by which you can reject administration regulations, and we can only do that in a very narrow path. Where we can do that every year, every day is in appropriations by taking away money that comes from bad behavior or bad ideas. We need to get out of the CR and get into an appropriations process again."

Go to: https://youtu.be/ZCCzRuJm-6I to watch Sen. Moran's interview on YouTube.

Read this original document at: https://www.moran.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/news-releases?ID=D0E0A5AD-B060-4AD5-9A05-C1987FFCE346

urn:contentItem:600V-7121-DXH2-6004-00000-00Sen. Rick Scott (R-FL) Is Interviewed About The Comments Of Andrew Cuomo; U.S. Coronavirus Death Toll Crosses 100,000; New Cases Rise Amid Re- openings; Protests And Riots Hit Minneapolis Third Precinct; Minneapolis On Edge After Man Dies In Police Custody; Fugitive Wanted In Two Killings In Connecticut Captured In Maryland; Democratic Governors Of Highly Populated States Under Scrutiny; Trump Attacks Social Media Outlets Over Alleged Bias2020-05-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:22ZLexisNexisFOX NEWS @ NIGHT11:00 PM ESTRick Scott, Benjamin Watson, Dan Patrick, Brendan Carr, John YooNEWSDomestic052701cb.259Sen. Rick Scott (R-FL) Is Interviewed About The Comments Of Andrew Cuomo; U.S. Coronavirus Death Toll Crosses 100,000; New Cases Rise Amid Re- openings; Protests And Riots Hit Minneapolis Third Precinct; Minneapolis On Edge After Man Dies In Police Custody; Fugitive Wanted In Two Killings In Connecticut Captured In Maryland; Democratic Governors Of Highly Populated States Under Scrutiny; Trump Attacks Social Media Outlets Over Alleged BiasShannon Bream, Mike Tobin, Trace Gallagher, Ted Williams, Kevin Corke, Rick Leventhal

LAURA INGRAHAM, FOX NEWS HOST: We don't need any more chaos. We need answers and we need justice.

That's all the time we have tonight. Make sure you tune in tomorrow. I'll have an exclusive interview with Secretary of State, Mike Pompeo, a lot of discuss with him. Shannon Bream, the "FOX NEWS @ NIGHT" team take it all from here. Shannon?

SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Laura, thank you very much. We begin on a busy night with Fox News alert.

The number of deaths from coronavirus in the U.S. reaching 100,000. But along with that some good news, the pace of deaths from COVID-19, which has shut down much of the country is actually slowing and it's measurable. It's also true that the pace of real openings is picking up across the country. What does the data tell us about cases in states that decided to lead the way?

But first, breaking tonight in Minneapolis. This is the scene now with looting and fires still going late into the night. Earlier, you saw our Mike Tobin got caught in the back and forth between rioters and protesters angry over the death of a black man at the hands of a Minneapolis Police officer and police outside the third precinct. Here's part of that.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE TOBIN, FOX NEWS CHANNEL CORRESPONDENT: There's one of those flashbangs, they're pretty close to us here. And there is some kind of a chemical irritant and there you see the pepper spray coming out from the police. I got the pepper spray in my eyes.

So that's seen out here. A lot of back and forth with these demonstrators in the cops.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: Hello and welcome to FOX NEWS @ NIGHT, I'm Shannon Bream in Washington. Let's go straight to Mike now live in Minneapolis for the very latest on the situation there at this late hour, and this has been going on as you've tracked it for hours there, Mike, on the ground. What can you tell us?

TOBIN: Well, it doesn't really seem to be calming down as night has fallen. You can see there are a lot of demonstrators behind me just about a block away from the third precinct from which those officers were dispatched.

And we're watching this go on through the night. These demonstrators are angry. They understand that the officers were fired. They understand that the President said he's going to expedite an investigation with the FBI and the DOJ., but for them, it's not fast enough and they don't trust the people involved in the system. Here's some of what they had to say.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: These people supposed to be protecting and serving us, you know, yes, some that may have happened that was wrong, but at the end of the day, did his life deserved to be taken? You know, I'm saying who's supposed to protect us against those that's supposed to protect us?

TOBIN: Let's see, this is the...

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm holding a sign.

TOBIN: Let's see it.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Protesting the murder of somebody and I'm getting shot at.

TOBIN: And what he says is that is the wound from a rubber bullet just like this one, you're getting a lot from all the way up at the president who said he's going to -- he says he's going to launch the DOJ and the FBI in this investigation. Why is that not enough? Why not pause and let the wheels of justice go?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Because this president has been holding the truth about a damn thing so why should I believe he's going to start doing it now?

TOBIN: To you, the wheels of justice are just aren't moving fast enough, correct?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: No. They're not moving at all. They're not moving at all.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

TOBIN: And fire crews are now at the scene at that auto parts AutoZone store. We saw that an hour ago. The witnesses said it was started with a box of fireworks, it was deliberately set on fire inside of that AutoZone.

It's also not a short distance away from the Target. It hadn't been inside of it yet. But I understand the Target has been gutted with these angry demonstrators out on the street. The fire crews are at the AutoZone, there's a lot of black smoke, billowing from the AutoZone. I can't really tell just what state the fire is in.

As I come back and have a look, you've got a lot of people on the street and you've got some more fireworks. They're all running right now, because that's the tear gas coming out of the officers. And I was trying to avoid the crowds and the crowd came to me here.

That's our scene right now. We got people throwing things back at the officers. Now those are the officers at the third precinct and they're basically guarding the building. And now the tear gas is on the street. They did a pretty good job of clearing the street with the tear gas time.

And some of what you're looking at the background is also just homemade, or, you know, roadside fireworks that the protesters bought, and they're lighting off in the middle of it. So you can't be confusing that with a non-lethal weaponry that the police are using to disperse the crowd.

But they just fired off all that tear gas and it looked like it did a pretty good job of clearing, what is Sixth Street here. You got the tear gas, you got the fireworks going off at the same time, Shannon.

BREAM: And, Mike, if you could hear me, let me ask you. This is centered around the third precinct there, the police headquarters. We've seen different images of damage and some aggressive action involving the police precinct there. Can you tell us where the situation stands right now as far as damage to that building, the posture that police are in as they are now having incoming and trying to manage that while keeping people safe and giving them the freedom to protest where they are doing so peacefully?

TOBIN: Well, the posture keeps changing for the police. As for the building itself, a lot of broken out windows and boarded up doors. The police were taking a posture where they had on helmets. They had truncheons, they had some things like pepper spray with them. They did not have on the heavy body armor that we see sometimes with riot police. They didn't have riot shields with them.

But that being said, we've seen the bite cops out here as well. And we've seen the horse-mounted police, a large, for lack of a better term, squadron or platoon of horse-mounted Police just came up the street a short time ago, it cleared out the street, just like the tear gas did, but then the protesters seemed to backfill as soon as the presence has gone. Shannon.

BREAM: OK. And one last quick question for you now, Mike, because we want you to be safe and get to safety if you need to move from there. Your assessment initially off the top was this doesn't seem to be calming down, as things are getting later.

In your assessment just from whatever vantage point you have, is the crowd growing? Is it dispersing? Where do things feel like they're headed at this moment?

TOBIN: Well, you're going to see it disperse right now because a couple fresh rounds of tear gas just came in. And so, the kids all scatter. And I shouldn't call them kids because there are some adults out here. But the people will all scatter, and then they'll come back. They've got the pepper spray out now as well.

But, yes, we tried to pick a point where there weren't that many people primarily out of concerns with COVID-19 or been too far into the crowd. Don't do what I do, do what I say. But there's more pepper spray coming. We got to back up. I've had enough spray for one night.

BREAM: Ok, Mike. You get to safety. We'll stay in touch with you. Thank you. Yes, thank you for your eyes there on the ground and keeping us factually updated and we'll check back with you, but please, get to safety, Mike.

OK. We want to take from there to another breaking issue further West. Black Lives Matter staging its own protest tonight in Los Angeles, marching through downtown L.A. and blocking the 101 Freeway there. Now we're told the situation there has turned violent.

Chief breaking news correspondent, Trace Gallagher, is on the case from our West Coast newsroom tonight to report on that side, is what you're looking at here. These are now live pictures in Minneapolis. Trace, what can you tell us further west?

TRACE GALLAGHER, FOX NEWS CHIEF BREAKING NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Yes, Shannon, it's hard to get an exact number but it appears anywhere from 500 to 1,000 people took part in this Black Lives Matter protest in Downtown Los Angeles. And apparently, the event wasn't cleared by city officials because the police presence was almost nonexistent, and the crowd, you could see was very much packed together with very few protesters practicing social distancing guidelines.

The protest was in response to the death, of course, of George Floyd in Minnesota. It began in L.A. City Hall late today then made its way through the streets of downtown and eventually, as you look at these pictures, that shut down the 101 Freeway before moving back off the freeway and onto the side streets, and there was some confrontation with police when dozens of protesters surrounded a California Highway Patrol cruiser.

And when the car tried to flee, the CHP car, you can see right there, somebody smashed the back window with a skateboard and then another man wrote on that hood you saw the man kind of fall off there, he hit his head on what appeared to be the concrete and remained on the ground motionless for a short time, but he was later seen with paramedics putting his fist up as if to say that he was OK.

When a second CHP car, you see there, tried to assist, the crowd also converged around that car smashing its back window as well. Both cars then left. It's unclear if they fled altogether or they move toward other protesters.

Local media reports there are still protesters in the downtown area. But there had been no more reports of disruptions or police confrontations, at least for the time being.

Today, Los Angeles Police Chief Michael Moore issued a statement calling the video of the Minnesota police officer disturbing, Shannon.

BREAM: OK. Trace, please keep us updated there on the West Coast. Thank you so much.

So two protests of George Floyd's death in two very different cities tonight across the U.S., both resulting in unrest that we continue to monitor at this hour. Again, this is live, I believe, from Mike Tobin's camera there in Minneapolis as there's back and forth with the police, as Mike has told us several times, and he's been on the receiving end of this, been close enough of it to get the tear gas, the pepper spray, and experienced that for himself.

But he says the crowds continue to be turned out in full force there tonight, sometimes dispersing with this police activity, but then staying on their ground and standing their ground and staying there.

So let's talk about how these events are playing out tonight with Fox News contributor, former Washington D.C. police detective, Ted Williams. Good to have you with us tonight, Ted.

TED WILLIAMS, FOX NEWS CHANNEL CONTRIBUTOR: Hi, Shannon. Glad to be with you.

BREAM: Let's talk about this situation. Our men and women in uniform, the vast majority of them excellent people who voluntarily choose to go on into very dangerous situations every day. There are situations that do require attention. There are lives lost and investigations to be had. They are launched now in this case.

How do the officers there now on the scene, walk this fine line between respecting people's first amendment rights, protecting the rights to be out there and to protest and to assemble and to push back and to raise attention versus where we've seen some of the things cross over into setting fires, vandalizing stores, and generally a situation that a lot of people think could escalate into something unsafe.

WILLIAMS: Yes. Well, it's this -- the murder should we say of George Floyd, has ignited these demonstrations there. And the law enforcement officers are trying to control the demonstrators. You know, Shannon, I was in Milwaukee, where we had rights. I was in Baltimore where we had right. I was in Ferguson, Missouri, for Fox where we had rights. And the one common thread that you find all that you've got people who are really upset about what is going on in their community.

And you have law enforcement on the other side who are saying, hey, look, all of us are not bad. What happened to George Floyd shouldn't happen to anyone. And when you got a man down saying, I can't breathe, I can't breathe, and you can see this on video. This is just reprehensible, it's shocking.

The law enforcement officers out there are certainly in a zone of danger. But over a period of time, I think that this all will in fact, calm down.

BREAM: Ted, when we see the officers that we did in that video from Monday, and they're bystanders, there are videos that looks right from area businesses, we're getting a number of angles on what happened and what transpired leading up to George Floyd's death, where does -- is it training that goes wrong? Is it the situation -- the officers in the situation, making a bad call on what they were dealing with? At what point do these officers cross the line into something that their training should have told them otherwise to do or protocol or policy should have told them this was not the way to handle this?

WILLIAMS: Well, first of all, as you saw in the video, you had officers standing around while this one officer had his knee on the neck of Georgia Floyd. That is not proper police training procedures, the training itself, are in essence went wrong. But also, you had, at least one rogue officer there.

Under no circumstances, no circumstances should you ever put your knee on the back of a man's neck. Maybe Trump would move to some other platform and that'll kill Twitter.

BREAM: Well, well, let's see. Good to have you both with us, gentlemen. Thanks for weighing in. We'll see you back here tomorrow night.

urn:contentItem:60HH-9MC1-F03R-N442-00000-00Sen. Ron Wyden accused Trump of 'working the refs' by pulling the renomination of an FCC commissioner who had questioned the president's executive order targeting social media companies2020-08-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:22ZLexisNexisSen. Ron Wyden accused Trump of 'working the refs' by pulling the renomination of an FCC commissioner who had questioned the president's executive order targeting social media companiesTyler Sonnemaker

Aug 04, 2020( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Democratic Senator Ron Wyden slammed Trump for withdrawing an FCC commissioner's renomination and accused him of "working the refs," in an interview with The Verge[1].The White House abruptly pulled its nomination[2] of MIchael O'Rielly to serve another term as FCC commissioner following his criticism of Trump's executive order[3]taking aim at social media platforms.Wyden co-authored Section 230, which granted legal protections to internet companies, helping pave the way for the modern internet and, more recently, drawing the ire of Trump and other lawmakers."This is a colossal Constitutional mess," Wyden said of the order, which experts have called legally dubious[4].Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories[5]. In an interview with The Verge[6] this week, Sen. Ron Wyden, a key voice in Congress on internet policy issues, accused President Donald Trump of "working the refs, bullying the tech companies, and forcing Twitter and other platforms to print his lies."In a surprising move Monday evening, the Trump administration withdrew its nomination[7] of Michael O'Rielly, a Republican, to serve another term as one of the five commissioners at the Federal Communications Commission.Wyden called the administration's reversal a "disaster" and warned that pushing nominees to the FCC — an independent agency — who only swear loyalty to the president could cause the agency to lose "any sense of independence," according to The Verge."One nomination after another is brought up, and the litmus test is: will the nominee do exactly what the president of the United States wants to do on any given issue at any particular moment?"

Wyden told The Verge.The Trump administration pulled O'Rielly's nomination just days after he expressed concerns about the FCC regulating how social media companies moderate content on their platforms, which Trump's controversial executive order[8] seeks to do by empowering regulators to curb the companeies' legal protections."The First Amendment protects us from limits on speech imposed by the government — not private actors — and we should all reject demands, in the name of the First Amendment, for private actors to curate or publish speech in a certain way," O'Rielly said during a virtual event[9] hosted by The Media Institute."Like it or not, the First Amendment's protections apply to corporate entities, especially when they engage in editorial decision making," he said.Trump issued the executive order[10] — which specifically named Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, and YouTube — in May after Twitter fact-checked his tweets[11] falsely claiming that mail-in ballots lead to voter fraud, alleging that the platforms are biased against him and conservative viewpoints.The order directs federal regulators, including the FCC, to review, and ultimately curtail, Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act[12], which gives social media companies broad legal authority to moderate speech on their platforms.Legal and tech policy experts said the order was legally dubious and wouldn't hold up in court. (It is already facing one such legal challenge[13])."The First Amendment protects Twitter from Trump. It does not protect Trump from Twitter," Ashkhen Kazaryan, the director of civil liberties at the libertarian think tank TechFreedom told Business Insider's Sonam Sheth and Ashley Gold[14].Wyden, one of the co-authors of Section 230 — which is widely credited with enabling the growth of today's internet platforms — also slammed Trump's order."This is a deeply flawed idea. Beyond the fact that this is a colossal Constitutional mess, I don't think even Donald Trump believes he's going to be able to get away with this," Wyden told The Verge.Trump isn't alone in his dislike of Section 230, however. Lawmakers on both sides of the aisle have ramped up their criticisms of Section 230 in recent months, but for very different reasons.Former Vice President Joe Biden has also called for Section 230 to be revoked[15], citing platforms' reluctance to enforce their policies against misinformation and hate speech, arguing the current law disincentivizes them from taking action because they're not held liable for content published by users.Republicans, in particular Sen. Josh Hawley, have pushed to get rid of Section 230 protections[16] in an effort to combat what they claim is anti-conservative bias by social media companies. Lawsuits alleging such bias have been largely rejected by courts, also on the grounds that the First Amendment doesn't apply to private companies. Read the original article on Business Insider[17] [ 1]: https://www.theverge.com/2020/8/4/21354244/ron-wyden-fcc-nomination-section-230-trump-order-vergecast-interview [ 2]: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-fcc-trump/trump-withdraws-nomination-of-republican-fcc-commissioner-to-serve-new-term-idUSKCN24Z2NI [ 3]: https://www.businessinsider.com/all-the-latest-news-about-trump-executive-order-social-media-2020-5 [ 4]: https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-executive-order-twitter-section-230-dead-on-arrival-2020-5 [ 5]: https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet [ 6]: https://www.theverge.com/2020/8/4/21354244/ron-wyden-fcc-nomination-section-230-trump-order-vergecast-interview [ 7]: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-fcc-trump/trump-withdraws-nomination-of-republican-fcc-commissioner-to-serve-new-term-idUSKCN24Z2NI [ 8]: https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-signs-executive-order-threatening-twitter-facebook-conservative-bias-2020-5?r=eo-landing [ 9]: https://docs.fcc.gov/public/attachments/DOC-365814A1.pdf [ 10]: https://www.businessinsider.com/all-the-latest-news-about-trump-executive-order-social-media-2020-5 [ 11]: https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-executive-order-social-media-explicitly-cites-personal-twitter-feud-2020-5 [ 12]: https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-section-230-internet-law-communications-decency-act-explained-2020-5 [ 13]: https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-administration-hit-with-first-lawsuit-executive-order-social-media-2020-6?r=eo-landing [ 14]: https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-executive-order-twitter-section-230-dead-on-arrival-2020-5 [ 15]: https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-biden-want-to-revoke-section-230-for-different-reasons-2020-5?r=eo-landing [ 16]: https://www.businessinsider.com/big-tech-liable-for-harmful-content-under-josh-hawley-bill-2019-6 [ 17]: https://www.businessinsider.com/wyden-trump-working-the-refs-pulling-fcc-o-riely-nomination-2020-8

urn:contentItem:5V6W-CG01-JC11-14HC-00000-00Sen. Rubio Introduces Privacy Bill to Protect Consumers While Promoting Innovation2019-01-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:22ZLexisNexisSen. Rubio Introduces Privacy Bill to Protect Consumers While Promoting InnovationTargeted News ServiceWASHINGTON

The office of Sen. Marco Rubio, R-Florida, issued the following news release:

U.S. Senator Marco Rubio (R-FL) today introduced the American Data Dissemination (ADD) Act, legislation that would provide a national consumer data privacy law that protects both consumers and the innovative capabilities of the internet economy. By using the Privacy Act of 1974 as its framework, the bill provides overdue transparency and accountability from the tech industry while ensuring that small businesses and start-ups are still able to innovate and compete in the digital marketplace. A one-pager of the bill is available here.

"There has been a growing consensus that Congress must take action to address consumer data privacy," Rubio said. "However, I believe that any efforts to address consumer privacy must also balance the need to protect the innovative capabilities of the digital economy that have enabled new entrants and small businesses to succeed in the marketplace. That is why I am introducing the American Data Dissemination Act, which will protect small businesses and startups while ensuring that consumers are provided with overdue rights and protections. It is critical that we do not create a regulatory environment that entrenches big tech corporations. Congress must act, but it is even more important that Congress act responsibly to create a transparent, digital environment that maximizes consumer welfare over corporate welfare."

Specifically, the ADD Act would do the following:

- Not later than 180 days after enactment of the ADD Act, the FTC is required to submit detailed recommendations for privacy requirements that Congress can impose on covered providers. These requirements would be substantially similar to the requirements applicable to agencies under the Privacy Act of 1974.

- Not earlier than one year after the date on which the Commission has submitted detailed recommendations (18 months after enactment), the FTC will publish and submit to the appropriate committees of Congress proposed regulations to impose privacy requirements on covered providers that are substantially similar to the requirements applicable to agencies under the Privacy Act of 1974.

- To ensure Congress acts in a timely manner, if the Congress fails to enact a law based on the recommendations provided by the date that is two years after enactment of this bill, the FTC would promulgate a final rule, not later than 27 months after the date of enactment to impose privacy requirements based on the narrow, congressionally mandated course of action created through this bill.

Earlier today, Rubio penned an op-ed (https://thehill.com/blogs/congress-blog/technology/425557-congress-needs-to-address-consumer-data-privacy-in-a) addressing the need for Congress to address consumer data privacy.

urn:contentItem:5RR3-S011-JB20-G4C4-00000-00Sensata Technologies Holding NV at Barclays Industrial Select Conference 2018 - Final2018-02-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:22ZLexisNexis022118a11269339.739Sensata Technologies Holding NV at Barclays Industrial Select Conference 2018 - Final

Corporate Participants

* Paul S. Vasington

Sensata Technologies Holding PLC - CFO, CAO & Executive VP

Conference Call Participants

* Brian Arthur Johnson

Barclays PLC, Research Division - MD & Senior Equity Analyst

Presentation

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON, MD & SENIOR EQUITY ANALYST, BARCLAYS PLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: Okay. Let's -- very pleased to have with us, once again at the Industrial Select Conference, Sensata Technologies Holding. We're covering it this year out of the automotive side. Last year it was in the industrial side, although I helped a former analyst with some of the insights into that and was on stage as well. I'm very pleased to have with us this year, Paul Vasington, EVP and CFO; and Joshua Young, VP in IR.

Why don't we start with a couple of the ARS -- you have this, the ARS questions. You've got your voting machines in front of you. And number one, do you currently own this stock? I think by now you know how to use the machines. Would you like to vote? You're from Boston. I'm from Chicago. We should always vote early and often.

PAUL S. VASINGTON, CFO, CAO & EXECUTIVE VP, SENSATA TECHNOLOGIES HOLDING PLC: Exactly.

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: If you have any deceased shareholders, they can vote, too. So yes, good attendance in the room with people who own the stock. Although -- and so we'll get to some of the bull/bear today (multiple speakers). There's a vocal minority there. Number two, what's your general bias towards the stock?

(voting)

PAUL S. VASINGTON: So we're having a little positive...

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: Well, I'd say the positive, negative and positives kind of match. (Multiple speakers), it was interesting, 10% were underweight, but there's 0% negative. So that might be a macro call or that might be something -- hopefully some of you will ask questions so I'm not the only one asking questions.

Why don't I first go in and just talk about how you kind of think about the organic growth potential? Sort of ex this cycle because, of course, we'll talk about HVOR and some of the good cycle trends there that've been negative in prior years. But just the fundamental ability of your end markets in auto, that outgrow production, in HVOR it'd outgrow commercial and our pilot production, in industrial generally, they outgrow GDP. How do you think about your portfolio in particular? Of the 8% of the revenues that you put into RD&E, how much of that would go into sort of brand-new applications? How much into -- at the other end of the spectrum, very mature applications? And the things in the middle, sort of maturing in high growth kind of applications?

PAUL S. VASINGTON: Okay. So just tackle the research, development and engineering question first. So about 8% of our revenue is in research, development and engineering, and that's split half around pure R&D, which is the new design and development work, and the other 4% is in sustaining engineering. It's working on existing products and modifications for existing product applications. Most of that 8% is underpinning growth. It's to launch new products. It's to design, develop and get new products ready for launch when the customer's ready. So I would say, it's highly, highly -- a high percentage of that is really related to our growth model and our growth engine.

If I think about the business organic growth potential, our Investor Day back in December, we talked about 4 trends that are shaping the industry. It's around clean and efficient, it's around electrification, autonomy and smart and connected. And over the next 3 years, we have an organic growth rate between 4% and 6%. We've talked about 90% of that business being secured, so we have a strong carryover business. Business we have today that carries on. As well as new business we won, which we'll launch over the next 3 years and generate revenue. And most of that is coming out of the clean, efficient and electrification trends, where autonomy and smart connected are very exciting opportunities for us, are a little bit further out in terms of their maturity. So that kind of lays out the -- why we're confident in the growth. The business that we have in place that will support that growth and our ability to execute, which is we believe is very high.

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: So let's talk first about automotive. Because in part, we had BorgWarner up on stage here earlier talking about the growth and evolving their business from pure internal combustion to hybrids, of course, to electrification. I guess, as we look at your growth rate this past year, it actually ticked up. There were some cyclical factors that abated, but it does look like -- and then again in Investor Day, that you're getting content outside the engine cylinder, the manifold, some of the traditional pressure-sensing markets. Could you maybe go back and kind of when did you start seeing, in terms of the electrification and the autonomous, the need or the opportunity to move beyond that? When did you begin to put into place some of the building blocks that are now coming into the revenue stream now?

PAUL S. VASINGTON: Okay. The one thing I wanted to add to the previous comment, what also overlays our growth and supports the organic growth is the modernization in China. So as the truck and auto fleets continue to modernize, that's great content growth for Sensata. We've talked about our content there going from $10 to $15, 150%. So that's another factor that you kind of align with those underlying industry trends that gives us great confidence in our ability to execute over the next few years. As it relates to electrification, we do see great content opportunity on hybrid vehicles. So vehicles with an advanced combustion system, the content opportunity there is greater than it would be on an existing gas powertrain vehicle. And we're really well prepared to serve that market. We talked about, we have part of our portfolio is electrified, right? So we're prepared to serve that, able to serve that. That's within our technology platform and the products that we offer.

As you start thinking about electrification, as it gets more towards EV, I mean, there's certainly things that we do today. We talk about having $25 to $30 of content on the Chevy Volt, as an example. So there are some small examples. That market hasn't really matured. It's hard to get a real view of what the average content will be, but we feel good about the technology we have today to serve the needs of customers today in terms of pure EV. We also see a lot of opportunity as those systems start to advance the electrical system, which is going to be focused on improving range and efficiency of those vehicles, that we're well-positioned with existing technologies to serve those needs. And we see a lot of exciting opportunities in other areas which we think we can intersect. We talked about things around thermal management and battery management systems as a way to do that, which has a lot more content than what we have today in terms of what we have on vehicles. So it feels as if there is a definite and identifiable tailwind that can come from the growth in pure electric vehicles over time.

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: So what you're saying is, even if, I don't know, a kind of customer in 2020 walks out of the showroom with an all-electric Mercedes or Tesla or BMW or whatever versus what they would have been buying in 2015, a gas or diesel 3 Series or 5 Series or E-class. You see the constant opportunities not only flat but could increase in that environment?

PAUL S. VASINGTON: Right. And we talked about on Investor Day, an example where if you think about the HVAC...

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: Multi-zone.

PAUL S. VASINGTON: Zone in a vehicle. Today, it's a sensor, one sensor, the air conditioning system, that expanding into sensors that manage heat and other thermal issues related to an electric vehicle. We think that those -- that's just incremental sensors that we would -- pressure sensors that we would not have today available to us. So as that system evolves and the needs become more apparent on what they have to manage and how they have to -- what they need to do to optimize the battery and the range of the vehicle, that's new content for Sensata that we would expect to see on that kind of a vehicle in the future.

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: Now in terms of sort of the buying groups, so they're the same buying groups, different buying groups?

PAUL S. VASINGTON: Well, it's the same. I think it's leveraging our existing relationship with those customers at the engineer level and we're working with those customers to find solutions to the issues that are developing as they move from -- move into hybrids and moving then into pure electric vehicle.

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: Now one of the things a lot of -- we had Aptiv up on stage earlier as well, and Borg as well, but one of the things people talk about in the automotive world as we move to electrification is it brings in potentially new competitors. Certainly, it's theory out there that if you're a legacy industrial automotive supplier, fine, you know the people and fossil fuel end of the business. But there's either big tech companies or Asian tech companies are active in things like electronics, power electronics. Do you see any of that in the sensing world in terms of a different competitor set showing up, say, for a battery, thermal monitoring, temperature system than say for a fossil fuel, fossil engine, the emissions control system?

PAUL S. VASINGTON: Yes, on the -- today's platforms, I think it's the same competitors, same level of competitive intensity. I think we're really well positioned to be successful as we see more and more hybrid vehicles on the road. On the EV side, I think others may be better suited to speak to this but so far, what we're looking at is how we take our existing technology in relation to the OEMs to help solve their problems. And then looking at new technologies where we think we can provide the unique value-differentiated option. And I don't think the market's mature enough to know where others may be intersecting that, that we're trying to intersect the same opportunities. I don't have that visibility and I don't see that today but you know...

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: One of the questions that comes up as well is, you bought Schrader in part to get into the Chinese -- to TPMS, which we know is about to boom and in the process of booming in China. So maybe, A, update on that. But secondly, seems like part of the rationale was to get into just wireless sensing. And we had Aptiv up earlier, as you know, they're active in electrical architecture. They're having dialogues with the big OEMs, the leading edge OEMs, particularly in Europe around how do we get wires out of the system? How do we move data around without necessarily having to run twisted pairs? So maybe could you update us on both those parts of the Schrader? Just kind of remind us where we are in the China inflection on TPMS. So then where are you taking that wireless sensing technology into either automotive or industrial applications?

PAUL S. VASINGTON: I guess, a couple of different pieces there. The first is, how is tire-pressure sensing adopting in China. There is regulation that's out there that will come into being in the 2019, '20 time frame. And so when we get to full adoption, full regulation, we think it's about a $100 million business. Today, it's about a $40 million business and we do think that there'll be a continued ramp-up in the revenues as not driven by regulation, but driven by consumer preference, where OEMs are seeing that that's a feature that consumers want. And so they're asking for that feature to be on the car sooner than regulation would otherwise require. So it's a growing business. It will ultimately increase $50 million or so over the next 3 years. And it will be somewhat of a gradual increase and probably more back-end loaded just because regulation will certainly drive it faster. But we are definitely seeing the growth there, and that's great.

In terms of the wireless capability, what we're doing with pressure sensing, which is part of what we considered when we bought Schrader, is the ability to take their tire-pressure sensing in the automotive market and bring that to the truck market. Although the truck market is regulated, owners are aware of and looking for using tire-pressure sensing to not only drive safety but increase the operating performance and the cost efficiency of the truck. And so there's natural adoption beyond regulation that's happening in the truck market. And then if you then take the fact that we have this wireless capability on the tire-pressure sensing, we're seeing the ability to use that to think about a smart-connected environment around a vehicle like a truck where you can create a network, which exists today for tire-pressure sensing, expand that to more sensors on the vehicle, to be able to sense more things, gather more data and provide that to users to run a more efficient -- wirelessly. Because the difference, it's hard (multiple speakers).

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: Is there any early application to that in the pipeline?

PAUL S. VASINGTON: So there's something we talked to investors that we're looking at and thinking that this is -- because of the wireless network, how do we build on that, bring more sensors on to the vehicle, provide more information to the user, to the owner, to the fleet manager, and do that wirelessly from the other cost-effective solution? So that's exciting. And then the other one would be in terms of when we think about battery management and the key things, staying in the range of electric vehicle, how do you get more out of the battery? How do you improve the health, the life of the battery? And being able to manage and understand what's happening at the cell level, but using wireless technology to be able to have that demand of that system, and then communicate that to the car to be able to optimize the performance and do that wirelessly.

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: So you can monitor at wireless points without having to additional (multiple speakers)

PAUL S. VASINGTON: And without having to wire it. And so that you take weight and cost and probably make the manufacturing process a lot easier by being able to do that in a wireless environment.

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: And if you talk about integrating the integration. Have you been able to take some of that wireless technology into some of the industrial markets like some of the things CST brought you?

PAUL S. VASINGTON: So another area to go explore, in how to use the wireless environment on the industrial side.

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: Which then gets to -- okay, you've got these sensors generating data, some coming through wires, but in future increasingly more coming through wireless. How does that position Sensata in a world of automotive big data or just more broadly, the industrial Internet of Things? And is it just -- how do you see that kind of driving your growth? And are there adjacencies where you're not just generating the data, but you're perhaps creating software and other systems that interpret it and act on it?

PAUL S. VASINGTON: I think for the most part, we're focused on the component, being a component supplier of the sensor, the measuring of the phenomenon and then providing the right data to upstream. But there are going to be pockets where we're going to want to move up more because we think we're in a unique position. And I think the one I just described around creating that network on a large vehicle, and whether it's big truck or a trailer, and leveraging our position that we have and then expanding upstream a bit because it makes a lot of sense. I don't -- strategically, that's not we're trying to drive the business across the business, but there will be situations where it makes a lot of sense and we're well positioned to be successful there and we'll likely want to go do that.

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: Okay. Let's bring up question number 3 about growth, and then I want to get to your other driver of growth. Through-cycle EPS growth for Sensata Technologies. And would you rather have this against the industrial peer group in the other rooms or versus the automotive peer group, your call? Shall we start the clock?

PAUL S. VASINGTON: No, that's fine. We want to be best-in-class.

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: So industrial?

PAUL S. VASINGTON: Yes.

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: Okay. So versus industrial peers. Which makes sense.

PAUL S. VASINGTON: Yes.

(voting)

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: Okay. So still above or in line with the group growing generally faster than automotive, at least this point in the cycle. Just one thing on the growth, and then I'll get to the margins. HVOR, which had been a headwind in terms of commercial and off-highway builds, now swinging. If we look at the strong recent growth in there, is there any way to dimension how much is just being in the right end markets at the right time? And how much is their end markets where that is happening, but there's also additional content, for example, I would imagine, Chinese construction and trucks?

PAUL S. VASINGTON: So the heavy vehicle and off-road business in 2017 grew 14%. That was with 8% -- 6% market growth, 8% content growth. And so a real strong performance. And we've always had content growth from that business, but we're seeing a lot more content growth now and into over the next 3 years, driven by just the need to continue to clean up exhaust systems, the transition from hydraulic controls on off-road vehicles to electronic controls and interfaces. So there's a lot of great content that's happening over the next 3 years in a business that is having a stronger market than in the past 3 years. And just for everyone's knowledge, I mean, they -- our heavy vehicle and off-road business is in a number of different markets. It's North America truck, it's Class 8, there's Class 5 to 7; it's European truck; it's global construction; it's global agriculture. And then there's some other smaller businesses around motorbikes and RVs that we also serve as well through the HVOR business. So there's a lot of different markets.

But generally, the market growth has been much stronger than in the last 3 years and that's across the board. And as we look forward to 2018, we're expecting 4% to 5% growth, market growth, production growth in our heavy vehicle and off-road business. On average -- it's on average across all those end markets. And over the 3 years, we talked about 3% growth in market production. So the growth will start to slow from the market, but the content growth will continue to be strong. And so it's going to be in that 6% to 8% range over the next 3 years. So very, very positive, strong content tailwind out of that business.

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: So if end markets (multiple speakers)

PAUL S. VASINGTON: And the other thing that's happening is tire-pressure sensing, as I mentioned earlier, is becoming an important content growth driver for that business. So again, taking the Schrader capability around passenger vehicle, bringing that into the truck market, seeing a lot of adoption because it drives efficiency and safety in those -- for those truck owners.

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: So obviously, revenue growth is one way to grow EBIT and EBIT margins through incremental profitability. But what gives you confidence in the EBIT margin expansion of 110 basis points in 2018, 250 basis points over a 3-year period? What gives you confidence? And maybe start -- and I apologize if this is buried in the investor deck, but kind of how much of that is coming from organic growth flowing through and sort of incremental 15% to 20% or so, plus or minus? How much is coming from just shifting to some higher margin products? And then how much is coming from your back-end efficiencies, everywhere from further merger integration to the supply chain efforts you've been talking about?

PAUL S. VASINGTON: So I'll stick with what we laid out in the investor deck that helped bridge the earnings growth over the 3-year period. The first thing is we're going to have a benefit because we're going to have less integration spend. So we had $20 million in 2017, and that's going to be $4 million or $5 million in 2018 as we finish up some of the integration work that we have for both Schrader and CST. So that gives you a tailwind going from '17 to '18 and it continues over the 3-year period. Synergies that we're achieving as we complete the manufacturing moves around Schrader, CST and some other product conversion work we're doing. That generates another $20 million over the next few years, which is, again, that's going to be a margin tailwind. So taking cost out of the existing cost base.

And then the rest is going to be just the normal productivity initiatives that we have around offsetting price concessions that we see in our automotive business by productivity gains on the cost side for the parts that we're producing. And then we also get operating leverage. So there's fixed cost in the business, and it's a highly variable cost business, but there are some fixed costs where we get operating leverage so we're growing incrementally our volumes higher than our EBIT. And so that also helps bring margin expansion.

Offsetting that will be the need to continue to invest in the business for the growth that we've won. So we won an NBO. It's a new business win. It takes a number of years to bring that product to market. You have to work with your -- particularly on your -- on the auto and the aerospace side, to work with them to design and get that product ready for production, and that requires investment. And so that is a good investment because it supports the growth that we're going to see over the next 3 to 5 years. And then there's also the investment that we're making to intersect the growth trend that are more in the future around electrification, autonomy and smart and connected. So that's additional investment that we think makes a lot of sense to support those emerging growth trends.

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: Now you've guided cash flow up 30% in '18, 19% over the longer time. How much of that is driven just by the EBIT? And then what are the other cash levers that we should be thinking about?

PAUL S. VASINGTON: I think the -- a couple of things that stand out. One is the higher earnings. Secondly would be an improvement in terms of working capital management, and that improvement comes from completing the transitions related to the sites that we're integrating. So the transitions take time, the new -- the receiving site needs to get their production up and running and qualified. And so we've built a lot of stock inventory to support that transition to make sure that our customers are going to be served flawlessly as we transition. So we've built a bunch of inventory to enable those transitions to take place and we'll work that inventory down in 2018.

Now, we're growing so we're still going to have growing working capital, receivables will grow as we grow. But that change in terms of kind of working through that temporary elevation inventory will also generate strong cash flows in '18. And then we've been doing a lot of restructuring the last couple of years, and so we had quite a bit of restructuring spend in 2017 that doesn't repeat at the same level in '18. So those will be 3 things that help support that free cash flow growth above the earnings growth.

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: Let's bring up question number four. And then, also, does anyone -- which is what should you do with the excess cash? Because I do want to talk about capital allocation.

(voting)

So bolt-on M&A, share repurchases, dividends, debt paydown. I want to pause there. Is there any questions from the audience? Okay. Well, let's then talk about capital allocation. Actually, if you could leave that numbers up because it's a good thing to talk around. Given that strong cash flow, at least in our model we have your leverage dropping to 2.2x. You've actually only talked about a target of 2.7x to 3x, I believe. So are you leaving room in that for share repurchases? 27% of the people like it, which is a dead tie with bolt-on M&A. And is there an acquisition, kind of, B, budget, or B -- and B, direction we ought to be thinking about?

PAUL S. VASINGTON: So the last couple of years, we've been deleveraging to get our leverage in a range which we feel very comfortable with. 3x feels comfortable. It's, for Sensata, given our desire to grow and to be acquisitive, it feels like the right place. It gives us access to the capital markets at the right pricing that we would like to get in terms of raising capital. And so with that, and then concerning the free cash flow that will be generated over the next few years, we feel we're in a great place to think about how we deploy capital in a balanced, return-driven way. And so we're talking about M&A, M&A being the area where we expect to get the highest returns. So with 15%, 20% internal rate of return. We showed you examples of Schrader at above 20%. We showed examples of CST at 13% to 15%, which is where we thought when we first bought the company. So we have those expectations of M&A and those returns are obviously higher than buying back shares because there's greater risk. But we also think there will be a time for share repurchase makes a lot of sense, where economically, it delivers for greater returns than any other option we have available to us.

And so it's going to be balanced. It's going to be returns-driven. It's going to be economic-based. And we just -- we're now in a better position to do that. And also with our redomicile to the U.K., which I would say that we -- thank you for those shareholders who supported that, that was approved by shareholders. So we're moving forward to the next stage of the merger process. That gives us a lot more optionality and flexibility to be able to distribute capital back to shareholders in a more effective way. So we're much -- we're just in a better position: strong cash flows, better leverage, better execution, to be able to generate high returns for shareholders through capital deployment.

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: Okay. Kind of related to capital deployment, how do you think about ROIC at your company? And you have very strong margins, but at least in your definition of ROIC, it's kind of 12%. And others, I mean, some OEMS we won't mention who define ROIC very creatively and get to 30%. But does your forecast for EBIT improvement improve that ROIC? Are there actions, [white tides] in here in terms of reducing cash or other parts of invested capital? You mentioned finished goods inventory that improved there.

PAUL S. VASINGTON: So we'll get back to about 13.5% in 2020, based on our definition. And that doesn't assume any aggressive new capital allocation. That's just kind of keeping the share count flat. And so depending on what we do on capital deployment, we can improve that outcome. And certainly, if acquisitions ultimately will initially be a drag, depending on the profit. Because we're not buying -- we're buying companies that have less profitability than we do. And so we try to spend an appropriate amount. If we get those 15% to 20% returns, we get the synergies we're expecting, eventually the ROIC will go up. But even without any deployment, we're going to move this up 150 basis points or so over the next 3 years.

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: Let's ask question number five. Well, both full of 2018 earnings. So it's inside the [trade desk]. This is the same range for everyone.

(voting)

So it's a pretty spikey distribution, right around 16 to 18. How do you think about that? And how do you think about it especially in light of acquisitions?

PAUL S. VASINGTON: When we -- going back to talking about our peer group, which we showed at the Investor Day, we think that's a great peer group to compare ourselves to into -- and to benchmark of our performance. And in many of the cases, we're performing at the median or above around earnings growth, margin performance, EPS growth, without having a real capital deployment. We're not buying shares. And so just organically through earnings growth. And so we do think that it's a compelling argument that, relative to that peer group and our performance, that the multiple has room to expand. And so that's certainly 60%. 16x or above is a good sign; (multiple speakers) alignment there.

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: Let's bring up question number six. What do you see as the most significant investment issue? It'd be interesting to see how this compares to last year. The multiples were up 2x, roughly, over last year. But I mean, the market is up, but then you had actually there some people supporting a much higher multiple. So core growth, 58%, similar to 5 years, a little bit higher than last year. And yes, so I think describing -- how do you think about number three? So like more people are thinking capital deployments can (inaudible). I guess, that's to get to the fact that you're now within your leverage targets, and hence that's probably a good thing.

PAUL S. VASINGTON: Yes, I think it is. I mean, the core growth, I guess it's an issue for 58% of the folks.

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: The other interesting thing. I was looking at number four. The -- just raw execution has dropped off appreciably.

PAUL S. VASINGTON: That's good. If I'm reading the chart right, that's about (multiple speakers).

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: Yes, yes. So it's probably -- you've sort of come through that period where the organic growth is mushy with the end markets moving around.

PAUL S. VASINGTON: The only comment I'd say about the core growth is 4% this year, 4% to 6% over the next 3 years. And I guess for me, the backdrop there is that we're growing and still growing very profitably. And so we're -- the value of that growth in my mind is very good. And so combining the 2 I think it's really important from how Sensata operates and what our strategic objectives are.

BRIAN ARTHUR JOHNSON: Great. Thank you, Paul. Thank you, Josh. Thank you, folks. Remember, we have a reception at the end of the day after the analyst roundtable.

PAUL S. VASINGTON: Thanks a lot. Appreciate it.

urn:contentItem:5PY5-1FN1-DY7P-R42W-00000-00Sense of the Markets: Fox, Disney and the Global Media Business2017-11-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:22ZLexisNexisSense of the Markets: Fox, Disney and the Global Media Businessby Leon Lazaroff

A far-reaching deal between Twenty-First Century Fox Inc. (FOXA) and Walt Disney Co. (DIS) may not transpire, but even if it doesn't, the premise of the talks reflects a sobering reality for the traditional television and film companies that have dominated media and entertainment for the past 50 years.

"Everybody is trying to figure out, 'What's my company look like, and how do I compete with Google and Facebook and Amazon and Netflix and Apple?'" said Mike Kelly, CEO of media consultancy Kelly Newman Ventures LLC and a former president of AOL Media Networks. "And being more competitive with those guys means you need a direct relationship with the consumer."

And that's something Fox doesn't have. Neither does Discovery Communications Inc. (DISCA), despite https://www.thestreet.com/story/14249384/1/billionaire-john-malone-s-free-radical-roll-up-propels-discovery-s-buyout-of-scripps.html|agreeing to spend $11.9 billion to buy Scripps Networks Interactive Inc. (SNI). The same goes for AMC Networks Inc. (AMCX) and Viacom Inc. (VIAB). Time Warner Inc. (TWX) didn't have one either, until CEO Jeff Bewkes convinced his board a year ago that the company needed to sell to AT&T Inc. (T).

Arguably, CBS Corp. (CBS) is building that relationship with All Access and Showtime, though even the path to lasting salvation for broadcast networks is paved with questions about demographics and the future of TV sports rights.

But back to Fox.

If CNBC's reporting of the potential transaction was in part of means of floating a trial balloon to gauge investor sentiment, the verdict is clear: The market likes this deal. Fox shares had sunk 5.4% this year before https://www.cnbc.com/2017/11/06/21st-century-fox-has-been-holding-talks-to-sell-most-of-company-to-disney-sources.html|CNBC reported on Monday, Nov. 6, that Fox officials had spoken with their Disney counterparts about selling their TV and film production studios, cable networks such as FX, the Star India networks and the company's 39% stake in European satellite TV operator Sky plc.

Disney also would acquire Fox's stake in Hulu LLC, the subscription platform jointly owned with Comcast Corp. (CMCSA) and Time Warner, riding recent momentum built off "The Handmaid's Tale."

Fox and Disney representatives declined to comment on the deal talks.

Fox shares have surged 13.1% this week through Tuesday afternoon, to $28.25, in the wake of the report. Disney hasn't gained as much, but importantly, the shares have advanced. Disney is up 3.4% this week.

Fox in the above scenario would retain its broadcast network, its regional sports networks, the fast-growing FS1 sports channel, the Fox News Channel and its TV broadcast affiliates. The Murdochs would be left with a trimmed-down company built around news and, especially, sports. Not to mention a lot of cash to build something new and, potentially, unencumbered by pay-TV or brick-and-mortar movie theaters. 

The premise of the deal, though, is both astonishing and sobering. The Murdochs apparently have determined that Fox, a company with $28.5 billion in annual revenue, may not have the scale, or a logical path to scale, to compete in this next chapter of the global media and entertainment business. It failed three years ago to https://www.thestreet.com/story/12834725/1/murdoch-rebuffed-as-fox-withdraws-bid-for-time-warner.html|buy Time Warner for $89 billion and lost out back in 2011 in its bid to acquire the remainder of Sky it doesn't own. U.K. regulators may ultimately reject its   https://www.thestreet.com/story/14336396/1/fox-gets-decision-it-didnt-want-on-sky-deal.html|latest bid as well.

Of course, the outlines of media's future have been clear for a few years. Cord-cutting is putting the squeeze on cable networks while technology players are fast entering the content business, proving that anyone can make TV serials if they have a few extra billion dollars. And many do. Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) already has jumped into the film and TV business, and Apple Inc. (AAPL) is building some kind of https://www.thestreet.com/story/14273692/1/apple-has-a-big-tv-budget-but-still-needs-a-hit.html|production studio. Facebook Inc. (FB) just launched its   https://www.thestreet.com/story/14361627/1/facebooks-watch-platform-eventually-will-replace-pay-tv.html|Watch tab, and Alphabet Inc.'s (GOOGL) Google just started   https://www.thestreet.com/story/14193133/1/youtube-tv-just-needs-a-fraction-of-overall-youtube-viewers-to-crush-cable.html|YouTube TV, its digital television platform.  

"Big media companies are in this enormous transition between linear, where they controlled their own distribution, to a nonlinear, digital world where they have the opportunity at least to have a direct relationship with the consumer," Kelly said. "But that costs a lot of money."

And money is something that Big Tech has in spades. Its players also have built direct-to-consumer platforms, leveraging their talent for technology in ways that Disney and Fox have been (very) slow to embrace. Amazon, Facebook, Apple and Google all have direct relationships with consumers. And so does Netflix Inc. (NFLX), of course. 

Fox, despite its enormous TV and film production studios, remains beholden to pay-TV operators and movie theaters. That paradigm is slowly changing as Fox pushes more of its content to Hulu and 20th Century Fox president Stacey Snider calls to https://www.thestreet.com/story/14347304/1/netflix-doubles-down-on-movies.html|shorten the window between a film's release and its availability for streaming.

If Disney is willing to take cable networks FX, FXX and National Geographic in a deal headed by 20th Century Fox and its television studios, that would free the Murdochs of trying to figure out how to sustain a business under pressure from fewer subscribers and advertiser migration to Google and Facebook. Yet even then, FX may be too edgy for the Disney brand.

The deal essentially would cut Fox in half, according to Bernstein Research's Todd Juenger. Roughly $40 billion in assets would be sold to Disney, and roughly $40 billion in assets would remain at a slimmed-down Fox. (A related question is whether a reduced Fox would then remerge with News Corp. (NWSA).

Of course, there's a very real possibility that this transaction never occurs. Companies talk all the time. It's the fiduciary responsibility of top executives to forever contemplate mergers and acquisitions.

What is clear is that the Murdochs appear open to selling some of their businesses. There are lots of moving pieces in a company as larger as Fox, but apparently many of those pieces are in play. There's no reason an Apple or Amazon, or even CBS, wouldn't consider acquiring the 20th Century Fox film studio or its television studios. 

It's very possible that these talks finally spark the M&A wave that media industry observers have been expecting for years. Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix and Google already have crashed the party.

DEAL SIZE

Undisclosed

urn:contentItem:5HBK-FTF1-JBYT-H4W6-00000-00Sensex ends down 38 points; Tata Motors jumps 6%, RIL, Sun Pharma drag2015-11-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:22ZLexisNexisSensex ends down 38 points; Tata Motors jumps 6%, RIL, Sun Pharma dragMumbai

Mumbai, Nov. 4 -- Indian benchmark stock indices, Sensex and the Nifty, closed lower on Wednesday. The indices failed to sustain the gains in late afternoon trade and slipped into negative territory.


The Sensex ended down 38 points or 0.14 per cent at 26,552.92 while the NSE Nifty shed 20.50 points or 0.25 per cent at 8,040.20.
The Sensex had gained 31.44 points in the previous choppy session.
Auto makers surged after Tata Motors reported strong October sales, but foreign sales capped broader gains.
Tata Motors gained 6 per cent, hitting its highest intra-day level since July 13, driven by strong JaguarLand Rover sales in North America in October. M&M (+1.71%), Bajaj Auto (+1.41%), Coal India (+1.4%), Hero MotoCorp (+1.19%) and SBI (+0.95%) were among the prominent gainers.
US shares climbed for a fifth consecutive day on Tuesday, boosted by energy shares, pushing up Asian shares.
Foreign investors sold about Rs 450 crore ($68.73 million) worth of shares on Tuesday and have been net sellers, selling Indian shares in four out of the past seven sessions.
"Data from the US was supporting market in the opening session and the market had already entered into the oversold region yesterday," Alex Mathews, head of research at Geojit BNP Paribas, said.
Shares in DLF gained as much as 4.77 per cent in intra-day deals after the Supreme Court rejected the market regulator's plea to prevent DLF from selling stake in its rental arm. It finished the day at Rs 122.15, up Rs 2 or 1.66 per cent. The ruling came a day after India's biggest listed property developer posted a 21 per cent jump in quarterly profit on lower costs even as home sales are slow to pick up in a recovering economy.
Shares in Nestle India rose as much as 4 per cent during the day after the company said samples of its noodle snack Maggi have been cleared by three laboratories. The stock ended the day at Rs 6,247.15, up Rs 12.80 or 0.21 per cent.
European shares rose on Wednesday, although Germany's blue-chip index sharply underperformed after a scandal at carmaker Volkswagen widened.
Volkswagen fell 10 per cent after it said it had understated the fuel consumption of 800,000 cars sold in Europe. Majority stakeholder Porsche was down 9.5 percent after it warned that VW's latest findings could weigh further on its results.
Japanese and Chinese stocks led Asian markets higher, helped by economy-friendly comments from China's President Xi Jinping, while on Wall Street, a rise in big tech and energy firms helped the Nasdaq 100 to close at a record high.
The rally in the United States started in late European trade, and helped to tilt the FTSEurofirst 300 into positive territory on Tuesday. The index closed up 0.4 per cent at 1,494.21 points.
In a busy day for economic data, there were set to be final PMI readings in the euro zone and the United States, with a U.S. ADP national employment report also in focus.

urn:contentItem:5X95-44G1-DXMP-K11P-00000-00Sensex, Nifty gain traction to trade at day's high2019-10-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:22ZLexisNexisSensex, Nifty gain traction to trade at day's high

The broader indices were trading in green; the BSE Mid cap index was up by 1.37%, while Small cap index was up by 0.74%

Indian equity benchmarks gained traction in late afternoon deals to trade at day's high points, mirroring firm European markets. Traders got comfort with a report that the digital payment system that has been developed in India not only allows big tech companies to participate in it but also has convenience, ease of use, low cost and financial inclusion. Adding some optimism, capital markets regulator SEBI reconstituted its Primary Market Advisory Committee (PMAC) that advises it on policy framework, development of initial public offerings and other such segments.

On the global front, European markets were trading in green, as the euro area trade surplus increased in August on falling imports. The data from Eurostat revealed that the trade surplus rose to a seasonally adjusted EUR 20.3 billion in August from EUR 17.5 billion in July. Exports grew 0.4 percent from the previous month, while imports declined 1.2 percent in August. However, Asian markets were trading in red.

Back home, realty sector stocks were in focus, amid report that the real estate market sentiment index has declined to the level seen during demonetisation and is expected to remain pessimistic for next six months, despite several measures taken by the government and RBI to boost demand in the sector.

The BSE Sensex is currently trading at 38959.16, up by 360.17 points or 0.93% after trading in a range of 38557.43 and 39010.73. There were 21 stocks advancing against 10 stocks declining on the index.

The broader indices were trading in green; the BSE Mid cap index was up by 1.37%, while Small cap index was up by 0.74%.

The top gaining sectoral indices on the BSE were Bankex up by 1.57%, Auto up by 1.37%, Consumer Disc up by 1.27%, FMCG up by 1.05% and PSU up by 1.02%, while Telecom down by 0.23%, Basic Materials down by 0.13%, Metal down by 0.12% and IT down by 0.01% were the top losing indices on BSE.

The top gainers on the Sensex were Yes Bank up by 16.28%, Indusind Bank up by 4.69%, Tata Motors - DVR up by 3.49%, SBI up by 3.30% and Tata Motors up by 2.42%. On the flip side, Vedanta down by 2.47%, Tech Mahindra down by 1.29%, HCL Tech. down by 0.95%, TCS down by 0.77% and ONGC down by 0.56% were the top losers.

Meanwhile, underlining unemployment as the country's biggest problem, Union minister Nitin Gadkari has expressed the need for policy measures to create jobs in rural areas and check migration to cities for employment. He also called for a detailed study to find out ways to skill people in tribal, agriculture and rural sectors and pointed out that skilled manpower was the biggest requirement in the country.

The minister further noted that the country's MSME sector has huge potential to create new job opportunities and there is a need to identify the areas where people can be skilled and given jobs. He highlighted several facts and figures like country's total 29 per cent growth/GDP comes from MSME sector, 49 per cent export is from MSME sector, till now 11 crore employment opportunities have been created.

Besides, Nitin Gadkari asked big companies across sectors to run skill development programmes and hire people according to their skills and suggested some ideas that can help create jobs in the country. He also said that there is need to find out ways to provide people job opportunities in their villages so they don't need to leave their homes.

The CNX Nifty is currently trading at 11554.60, up by 90.60 points or 0.79% after trading in a range of 11439.65 and 11565.30. There were 33 stocks advancing against 17 stocks declining on the index.

The top gainers on Nifty were Yes Bank up by 15.96%, Eicher Motors up by 5.42%, Indusind Bank up by 4.63%, SBI up by 3.26% and Zee Entertainment up by 2.45%. On the flip side, Vedanta down by 2.60%, Grasim Industries down by 1.40%, Tech Mahindra down by 1.31%, HCL Tech. down by 1.03% and TCS down by 0.88% were the top losers.

Asian markets were trading mostly in red; Nikkei 225 slipped 21.06 points or 0.09% to 22,451.86, Straits Times trembled 18.83 points or 0.6% to 3,115.88, Shanghai Composite declined 8.21 points or 0.28% to 2,970.50 and KOSPI fell 4.89 points or 0.23% to 2,077.94. On the flip side, Jakarta Composite soared 12.24 points or 0.2% to 6,181.83, Taiwan Weighted strengthened 24.05 points or 0.22% to 11,186.88 and Hang Seng increased 119.08 points or 0.45% to 26,783.36.

All European markets were trading in green; FTSE gained 34.51 points or 0.48% to 7,202.46, CAC rose 0.15 points or 0.01% to 5,697.05 and DAX was up by 20.73 points or 0.16% to 12,690.84.
