urn:contentItem:5X93-80S1-F12F-F2G4-00000-00Sensex, Nifty gain traction to trade at day's high2019-10-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:22ZLexisNexisSensex, Nifty gain traction to trade at day's highIndia

India, Oct. 17 -- Indian equity benchmarks gained traction in late afternoon deals to trade at day's high points, mirroring firm European markets. Traders got comfort with a report that the digital payment system that has been developed in India not only allows big tech companies to participate in it but also has convenience, ease of use, low cost and financial inclusion. Adding some optimism, capital markets regulator SEBI reconstituted its Primary Market Advisory Committee (PMAC) that advises it on policy framework, development of initial public offerings and other such segments.

On the global front, European markets were trading in green, as the euro area trade surplus increased in August on falling imports. The data from Eurostat revealed that the trade surplus rose to a seasonally adjusted EUR 20.3 billion in August from EUR 17.5 billion in July. Exports grew 0.4 percent from the previous month, while imports declined 1.2 percent in August. However, Asian markets were trading in red.

Back home, realty sector stocks were in focus, amid report that the real estate market sentiment index has declined to the level seen during demonetisation and is expected to remain pessimistic for next six months, despite several measures taken by the government and RBI to boost demand in the sector.

The BSE Sensex is currently trading at 38959.16, up by 360.17 points or 0.93% after trading in a range of 38557.43 and 39010.73. There were 21 stocks advancing against 10 stocks declining on the index.

The broader indices were trading in green; the BSE Mid cap index was up by 1.37%, while Small cap index was up by 0.74%.

The top gaining sectoral indices on the BSE were Bankex up by 1.57%, Auto up by 1.37%, Consumer Disc up by 1.27%, FMCG up by 1.05% and PSU up by 1.02%, while Telecom down by 0.23%, Basic Materials down by 0.13%, Metal down by 0.12% and IT down by 0.01% were the top losing indices on BSE.

The top gainers on the Sensex were Yes Bank up by 16.28%, Indusind Bank up by 4.69%, Tata Motors - DVR up by 3.49%, SBI up by 3.30% and Tata Motors up by 2.42%. On the flip side, Vedanta down by 2.47%, Tech Mahindra down by 1.29%, HCL Tech. down by 0.95%, TCS down by 0.77% and ONGC down by 0.56% were the top losers.

Meanwhile, underlining unemployment as the country's biggest problem, Union minister Nitin Gadkari has expressed the need for policy measures to create jobs in rural areas and check migration to cities for employment. He also called for a detailed study to find out ways to skill people in tribal, agriculture and rural sectors and pointed out that skilled manpower was the biggest requirement in the country.

The minister further noted that the country's MSME sector has huge potential to create new job opportunities and there is a need to identify the areas where people can be skilled and given jobs. He highlighted several facts and figures like country's total 29 per cent growth/GDP comes from MSME sector, 49 per cent export is from MSME sector, till now 11 crore employment opportunities have been created.

Besides, Nitin Gadkari asked big companies across sectors to run skill development programmes and hire people according to their skills and suggested some ideas that can help create jobs in the country. He also said that there is need to find out ways to provide people job opportunities in their villages so they don't need to leave their homes.

The CNX Nifty is currently trading at 11554.60, up by 90.60 points or 0.79% after trading in a range of 11439.65 and 11565.30. There were 33 stocks advancing against 17 stocks declining on the index.

The top gainers on Nifty were Yes Bank up by 15.96%, Eicher Motors up by 5.42%, Indusind Bank up by 4.63%, SBI up by 3.26% and Zee Entertainment up by 2.45%. On the flip side, Vedanta down by 2.60%, Grasim Industries down by 1.40%, Tech Mahindra down by 1.31%, HCL Tech. down by 1.03% and TCS down by 0.88% were the top losers.

Asian markets were trading mostly in red; Nikkei 225 slipped 21.06 points or 0.09% to 22,451.86, Straits Times trembled 18.83 points or 0.6% to 3,115.88, Shanghai Composite declined 8.21 points or 0.28% to 2,970.50 and KOSPI fell 4.89 points or 0.23% to 2,077.94. On the flip side, Jakarta Composite soared 12.24 points or 0.2% to 6,181.83, Taiwan Weighted strengthened 24.05 points or 0.22% to 11,186.88 and Hang Seng increased 119.08 points or 0.45% to 26,783.36.

All European markets were trading in green; FTSE gained 34.51 points or 0.48% to 7,202.46, CAC rose 0.15 points or 0.01% to 5,697.05 and DAX was up by 20.73 points or 0.16% to 12,690.84.

urn:contentItem:60XF-76D1-DYG2-R30F-00000-00Sens. Feinstein, Menendez Introduce Bill to Stop Fraudulent Online Gun Sales2020-09-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:22ZLexisNexisSens. Feinstein, Menendez Introduce Bill to Stop Fraudulent Online Gun SalesTargeted News ServiceWASHINGTON

Sen. Dianne Feinstein, D-California, issued the following news release on Sept. 24:

Senators Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) and Bob Menendez (D-N.J.) today introduced the Stop Online Fraudulent Sales of Firearms Act, a bill to prevent gun sellers from circumventing technology companies' terms of service by making it illegal to fraudulently sell firearms and ammunition online.

"While some technology companies have banned selling firearms and ammunition on their websites, the problem persists," Senator Feinstein said. "Our bill would make it illegal for gun sellers to circumvent websites' terms of service and continue the underground proliferation of firearms. It's part of a larger effort that needs to be taken to stop the plague of gun violence in our communities."

"The fact is, no matter how many times big tech companies claim they're cracking down on illegal online firearm sales, determined gun sellers and buyers find new ways to get around it," Senator Menendez said, who has continually called out Facebook for its failure to enforce and monitor its own ban on gun sales. "With this bill, we are making very clear to gun sellers who are caught illegally moving their weapons online: if you make the sale, you will pay the price."

Some technology companies have banned selling firearms and ammunition on their platforms. However, sellers use tactics like misrepresenting guns as other items to circumvent those restrictions.

For instance, sellers advertise on platforms like Facebook's Marketplace, claiming to sell stickers alongside images of gun makers' logos. Sellers typically ask an interested party to send a private message where buyers then learn the posting was actually for a gun sale and receive details and pricing.

Last month, Facebook reported it had removed 1.3 million pieces of content related to firearms between April and June 2020 from its platforms.

"Internet marketplaces like Facebook are the virtual dark alley where unscrupulous gun sellers go to meet dangerous individuals who are trying to get their hands on a firearm," said John Feinblatt, president of Everytown for Gun Safety. "Stopping these illegal sales would save lives, and we applaud Senators Feinstein and Menendez for introducing legislation to do exactly that."

"Overwhelming majorities of Americans support policies that ensure that individuals who should not possess firearms are not able to purchase them, including online," said Kris Brown, president of Brady. "Brady is grateful to Senators Feinstein and Menendez for addressing a dangerous practice of falsely advertising firearm sales online. Such sales are designed to circumvent the regulations that help keep our families and communities safe. This is a common-sense fix to a growing problem that applies the spirit of our nation's existing gun safety laws to novel, 21st century issues."

urn:contentItem:5YC5-9HV1-JC11-10PR-00000-00Sens. Markey and Blumenthal Introduce First-of-Its-Kind Legislation to Protect Children Online From Harmful Content, Design Features2020-03-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:22ZLexisNexisSens. Markey and Blumenthal Introduce First-of-Its-Kind Legislation to Protect Children Online From Harmful Content, Design FeaturesTargeted News ServiceWASHINGTON

Sen. Edward J. Markey, D-Massachusetts, issued the following news release on March 5:

* * *

- The KIDS Act addresses harms to children online, including amplification of disturbing and inappropriate content, damaging design features, and manipulative marketing

* * *

Senator Edward J. Markey (D-Mass.) and Senator Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.), members of the Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee, introduced the Kids Internet Design and Safety (KIDS) Act. As children and teens increasingly spend their time on platforms like YouTube, TikTok, and Snapchat, Congress has yet to implement key safeguards that protect young people's wellbeing in the current digital media environment. New research shows that by the age of 12 more than two-thirds of kids have their own smartphone, and more than twice as many young people watch videos every day than did in 2015. While kids are increasingly living their lives online, new reports have revealed the prevalence of violent and harmful content on popular platforms, the popularity of influencer marketing, and the adoption of design features, like auto-play, that effectively encourage young users to prolong their time spent on apps. Like the Children's Television Act did in 1990, the KIDS Act includes important advertising rules and protects children's interests as the ways that they consume media and entertain themselves evolves.

"Today, kids' faces are increasingly covered in the glow of their screens, and it's time to face the chilling reality that some websites and apps are built in ways that harm children," said Senator Markey, co-author of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA). "Powerful companies push kids to buy products at every turn online, and top platforms are saturated with disturbing content that no kid should ever be exposed to. As a society, we're playing catch up to the serious risks to kids online, and Congress has a responsibility to say loud and clear that Big Tech needs to get serious about the wellbeing of children and teens."

"Big Tech has designed their platforms to ensnare and exploit children for more likes, more views, and more purchases," said Senator Blumenthal. "Generations of kids are growing up in online spaces besieged by the crass commercialization of social media influencers, tobacco companies, fast food, and alcohol brands. The KIDS Act puts guardrails in place to reign in recklessness of marketers and Big Tech - protecting children and giving parents some peace of mind."

The KIDS Act addresses these trends and creates new protections for online users under 16 by:

Damaging Design Features:

* Banning "auto-play" settings lead to prolonged and unhealthy viewing sessions on websites and apps for kids and young teens.

* Banning push alerts that encourage kids and young teens to pull out their devices and increase screen-time.

* Banning badges that reward kids and young teens for increasing their time spent on an app or website.

Amplification of Harmful Content:

* Prohibiting kids and young teen websites from amplifying violent, inappropriate, and dangerous content.

* Requiring websites to implement mechanisms for users to report instances in which the website recommends harmful content to kids and young teens.

Manipulative Marketing:

* Prohibiting websites from recommending content that includes host-selling, or influencer marketing, such as "unboxing videos" to children and young teens.

* Prohibiting websites from recommending content that involves nicotine, tobacco, or alcohol to children and young teens.

* Prohibiting websites from exposing children and young teens to marketing with imbedded interactive elements.

"Senator Markey has been in this fight for thirty years, and Common Sense thanks him for his steadfast commitment to prioritizing the well-being of kids," said James P. Steyer, CEO and founder of Common Sense Media. "We urge Congress to pass the KIDS Act, legislation that would provide much-needed protections for kids online by regulating addictive and manipulative design and the commercial and inappropriate content that is currently served up to kids, containing violence, self-harm, and obscenity."

"This groundbreaking bill will provide children with the 21st Century safeguards they urgently need today," said Jeffrey Chester, Executive Director, Center for Digital Democracy."Children and teens are being subjected to an unprecedented array of harmful digital marketing practices that undermine their health, security and development. Children in the U.S. have been turned into digital "guinea pigs" as marketers and online platforms bombard them with commercial interactive applications designed to unfairly influence their emotions and behaviors. The "Kids Act" will ensure that young people will be able to grow up in a world where they are no longer exposed to these unaccountable outside forces."

"It's long been recognized that children are developmentally vulnerable to advertising and deserve special protections, which is why there are rules that prohibit certain kinds of ads on children's television. But for far too long, the internet has been a wild west where anything goes when it comes to marketing to kids," said Josh Golin, Executive Director, Campaign for Commercial-Free Childhood. "The KIDS Act will provide critical safeguards so that children using online and mobile platforms to learn and connect won't be exposed to unfair, manipulative marketing that undermines their wellbeing. We applaud Senator Markey for his leadership in standing up for kids and families."

"Much of the modern digital environment is designed by adults, for adults, to market and sell things. Despite the fact that children are avid users of browsers, games, social media, or easily-accessible general audience platforms, children are usually an afterthought in technology design or regulation," said Dr. Jenny Radesky, Assistant Professor of Pediatrics, University of Michigan Medical School. "As a result, the onus is on parents to help their child navigate a digital playground in which the platforms themselves are designed to promote arousing and commercial content. Senator Markey's KIDS Act seeks to change this status quo and push platforms and regulations to consider the interests and the health of kids in the context of online media platforms."

"The 'free' internet comes at a huge cost for kids, who are manipulated into watching a barrage of ads, and marketing disguised as content. For far too long the internet has been a wild west where anything goes, but the KIDS Act will provide critical safeguards so that children using online and mobile platforms to learn and connect won't be exposed to unfair, manipulative marketing that undermines their wellbeing. We applaud Senators Markey and Blumenthal for their leadership in standing up for kids and families," said Josh Golin, executive director, Campaign for a Commercial-Free Childhood.

A copy of the legislation can be found here. (https://www.markey.senate.gov/download/kids-act-2020)

Copyright Targeted News Services

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WDS-DDP1-DYG2-R39T-00000-00Sens. Warner, Hawley Introduce Bill to Force Social Media Companies to Disclose How They Are Monetizing User Data2019-06-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:22ZLexisNexisSens. Warner, Hawley Introduce Bill to Force Social Media Companies to Disclose How They Are Monetizing User DataTargeted News ServiceWASHINGTON

Sen. Josh Hawley, R-Missouri, issued the following news release:

Today, U.S. Sens. Mark R. Warner (D-VA) and Josh Hawley (R-MO) will introduce the Designing Accounting Safeguards to Help Broaden Oversight And Regulations on Data (DASHBOARD) Act, bipartisan legislation that will require data harvesting companies such as social media platforms to tell consumers and financial regulators exactly what data they are collecting from consumers, and how it is being leveraged by the platform for profit.

"When a big tech company says its product is free, consumers are the ones being sold. These 'free' products track everything we do so tech companies can sell our information to the highest bidder and use it to target us with creepy ads," said Senator Hawley. "Even worse, tech companies do their best to hide how much consumer data is worth and to whom it is sold. This bipartisan legislation gives consumers control of their data and will show them how much these 'free' services actually cost."

"For years, social media companies have told consumers that their products are free to the user. But that's not true - you are paying with your data instead of your wallet," said Senator Warner. "But the overall lack of transparency and disclosure in this market have made it impossible for users to know what they're giving up, who else their data is being shared with, or what it's worth to the platform. Our bipartisan bill will allow consumers to understand the true value of the data they are providing to the platforms, which will encourage competition and allow antitrust enforcers to identify potentially anticompetitive practices."

As user data increasingly represents one of the most valuable, albeit intangible, assets held by technology firms, shining light on how this data is collected, retained, monetized, and protected, is critical. The DASHBOARD Act will:

- Require commercial data operators (defined as services with over 100 million monthly active users) to disclose types of data collected as well as regularly provide their users with an assessment of the value of that data.

- Require commercial data operators to file an annual report on the aggregate value of user data they've collected, as well as contracts with third parties involving data collection.

- Require commercial data operators to allow users to delete all, or individual fields, of data collected - and disclose to users all the ways in which their data is being used. including any uses not directly related to the online service for which the data was originally collected.

- Empower the SEC to develop methodologies for calculating data value, while encouraging the agency to facilitate flexibility to enable businesses to adopt methodologies that reflect the different uses, sectors, and business models.

The DASHBOARD Act is the second tech-focused bill Hawley and Warner have partnered on. The first was Hawley's Do Not Track Act, which would be modeled after the Federal Trade Commission's (FTC) "Do Not Call" list and allow users to opt out of non-essential data collection.

A section-by-section summary of the bill is available here (https://www.scribd.com/document/414097487/Dashboard-Act-1-Pager).

urn:contentItem:60YJ-HW91-DXH2-61X2-00000-00Sen. Ted Cruz (R-TX) is Interviewed about the Debate, the Supreme Court Pick, Clinton's Plan and the Bombshell Report; Word on Wall Street; Rep. Kevin McCarthy (R-CA) and Rep. Michael McCaul (R-TX) is Interviewed about the China Task Force Report; Polls from the Fiery Debate; September's Tech Wreck.2020-09-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:22ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTTed Cruz, Mark Penn, Lee Munson, David Nelson, Michael McCaul, Kevin McCarthy, Lee Carter, Mark MahaneyNEWSFinancial093002cb.231Sen. Ted Cruz (R-TX) is Interviewed about the Debate, the Supreme Court Pick, Clinton's Plan and the Bombshell Report; Word on Wall Street; Rep. Kevin McCarthy (R-CA) and Rep. Michael McCaul (R-TX) is Interviewed about the China Task Force Report; Polls from the Fiery Debate; September's Tech Wreck.Maria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, September 30th. The end of the third quarter.

Your top stories right now, 7:00 a.m. on the button on the East Coast.

Sparks flying in Cleveland last night. A contentious debate between President Trump and former VP Joe Biden on a slew of issues, coronavirus, the economy, violence in America. Here's just one of the many heated exchanges of the night.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOE BIDEN (D), PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE: He talks about the art of the deal. China's made -- perfected the art of the steal. We have a higher deficit with China now than we did before. We have the highest deficit -- trade deficit with Mexico.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: China ate your lunch, down 18 (ph) percent.

CHRIS WALLACE, MODERATE: All right, gentlemen, in -- in --

TRUMP: China ate your lunch, Joe. And, no wonder, your son goes in and he takes out -- what -- he takes out billions of dollars.

BIDEN: No (ph).

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We have full analysis this morning. Up next, we'll hear from Texas Senator Ted Cruz coming up with his reaction.

Breaking news, something I first reported, now backed up by the bombshell new documents declassified by the director of National Intelligence, John Ratcliffe. Obama administration officials briefed on an investigative referral to the FBI that Hillary Clinton started the entire Russian witch hunt and approved the plan to vilify President Trump and stir up a scandal, all to distract from her own e-mail scandal.

This as Jim Comey is set to testify today in front of the Senate Judiciary Committee. We're on the latest declassified documents all morning long ahead of the Comey testimony.

Markets are in the red this morning on this, the final trading day of the month and the third quarter and the morning after the debate. Dow futures right now down 170 points, the Nasdaq futures down 64 and the S&P 500 down 16.25. Coronavirus cases, stimulus uncertainty also among the upsets for the market.

Yesterday as well, all three indices on pace to snap a five-month winning streak. Take a look, DowIndustrials were down 131 points at 4:00 on Wall Street yesterday. The Nasdaq down 30 plus points. And for the month, the markets are showing a decline of between 4 and 7 percent for the major averages.

Coming up, we're looking at what's next for the markets in the fourth quarter and where the opportunity lies.

MORNINGS WITH MARIA is live right now.

And European markets are also weaker. Investors rattled over a rise in coronavirus case there. Talks of a lockdown in the U.K. As you see, FT 100 down 13, the CAC quarante down 26 and the DAX index lower by 61.

A mixed story overnight in Asia. We had the China manufacturing purchasing managers index for the month of September. It came in above expectations at 51.5. Of course, this is coming from the Communist Party of China, so we are always skeptical of the numbers.

It was a fiery debate last night in Cleveland for sure. President Trump and Joe Biden going head to head during the first debate of 2020 and the presidential election. The two clashed on a number of issues, including the nomination of Amy Coney Barrett to the Supreme Court.

Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We have the Senate. We have the White House. And we have a phenomenal nominee.

JOE BIDEN (D), PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE: The American people have a right to have a say in who the Supreme Court nominee is. And that say occurs when they vote for United States senators and when they vote for the president of the United States.

TRUMP: Justice Ginsburg said very powerfully, very strongly, at some point, ten years ago or so, she said, a president and the Senate is elected for a period of time. But a president's elected for four years. We're not elected for three years. I'm not elected for three years.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is Texas Senator, Senate Foreign Relations and Judiciary Committee member, and author of the new book "One Vote Away," Senator Ted Cruz.

Senator, it's good to see you. Thank you so much for being here.

I've got to get your reaction. I know you met with Judge Barrett yesterday and your new book outlines the importance of filling the seat. So let me get to that in a moment.

Give me your reaction to the debate last night, Senator.

SEN. TED CRUZ (R-TX): Well, good morning, Maria.

It was raucous. It was wild. You know, it reminded me a little bit of watching a Detroit Pistons game in the 1980. There were a lot of hard fouls, a lot of missed shots.

At the end of the day, I don't know that it changed a whole lot of votes. I think all the people that were with President Trump are still with President Trump. And I suspect all the people that were with Joe Biden are still with Biden.

There were some good moments. There were some moments that stood out. By far, the president's best moment was when he clearly went after Joe Biden on the economy and the shutdown and he made clear that Joe Biden wants to shut down the economy, shut down small business and is destroying jobs and that the president wants to open up the economy and get people back to work and also get people back to school. And I thought Biden was pretty flat- footed in his response. That was the best moment for the president. But there were some pretty bumpy moments last night as well.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I agree with you that -- I mean I don't feel like you learned all that much and I don't think that it changed people's minds at this point, but, obviously, a raucous night.

Look, the issue of the Supreme Court came up. You write all about this and have studied this for so many years. You met with Judge Barrett yesterday. Tell me about that as you outlined in the book the importance of filling this seat. What was your expectation going into meeting Judge Barrett? Biden pushed back last night and said no, no, no, we should not be filling the seat until after the election.

CRUZ: Well, I met with Judge Barrett yesterday, spent about 45 minutes with her at the Capitol. I thought she was very impressive, very serious. She's got impeccable credentials, number one in her class at Notre Dame Law School, law clerk to Justice Scalia, law professor at Notre Dame for 20 years, one of the top federal appellate judges in the country. And, somehow, miraculously, she does all of that while at the same time being a mom to seven kids, which -- which I can't even imagine just doing the latter, much less doing everything else she does on top of that. I thought she's very impressive and a strong nominee.

You know, in the debate, I wish the president had talked a little bit more about why this debate -- this pick matters. His answer was essentially, I won, I'm president, I get to do this. OK, fine, but -- but -- but why does it make a difference to the American people? And -- and I think that -- that question is really important.

You mentioned my new book came out yesterday, "One Vote Away." The entire book is really why this makes a difference to the American people, because what it does is it breaks down the key issues before the court. But before I was in the Senate, I was a Supreme Court litigator. That's what I did for a living is argue cases at the Supreme Court. And every chapter of the book takes on a different constitutional liberty from free speech, to religious liberty, to the Second Amendment, to elections and democracy. And it really just tells war stories. It brings people inside, behind the curtain, to understand, all right, what's going on at the court, what are these issues, why does it matter to me. And it's really quite striking. On issue after issue after issue, our basic liberties that we count on, that we value, they were decided in landmark cases, many of which were 5-4 --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CRUZ: Many of which I played a really active part in litigating, that -- that -- that we're one vote away from losing those liberties. So I would have liked to see the president explain a little bit more why this nomination -- the American people chose him for a reason. They chose him to put Judge Barrett on the court and -- and I hope in the next debate that the president explains why that matters to the voters sitting at home watching the debate.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Yes, I saw yesterday the president tweeted out your book saying that our great First Amendment, great Second Amendment, our right to worship God, so much more comes down to one vote on the court. Ted Cruz has a fantastic new book out about it. Congrats on getting that -- that tweet from the president.

Walk us through what's at stake today, Senator, because this election may very well be contested on November 3rd.

CRUZ: Yes.

BARTIROMO: We're going to need a ninth voice there. We are expecting that the court is going to hear an argument against Obamacare pretty soon after the election. So what are the main issues that you think will be in front of Judge Barrett should she get appointed and confirmed?

CRUZ: Well, I think the whole gamut. And one of the things to remember is that Supreme Court nominations are typically measured in decades and not even years. It's one of the reasons why you don't necessarily focus on one particular case coming up next term or the term after because 30 years from now nobody remembers what those were.

And, you know, in the book, for example, I have a chapter on free speech that talks about the Citizens United case. Now most people have heard of Citizens United, but they don't really know what was at issue there. They know the Democrats hate the case.

Citizens United was about the First Amendment right that all of us have as Americans to criticize politicians. And what happened there is a small non- profit called Citizens United made a movie critical of Hillary Clinton. And the Obama Justice Department took the position that they could fine them and punish them for daring to make a movie critical of Hillary Clinton. And the case went all the way to the Supreme Court.

There was a really chilling exchange at the oral argument where Justice Sam Alito asked the Obama Justice Department, said under your theory of the case, could the federal government ban books? Could they ban books if the books are critical of a politician? And the Obama DOJ said, yes, yes, the federal government can ban books. It was a radical interpretation of the First Amendment.

Now, thankfully, the Supreme Court rejected that 5-4. But there were four justices prepared to say the federal government can ban movies, can ban books if they're critical of politicians.

BARTIROMO: Yes (ph).

CRUZ: That dramatically weakens our First Amendment rights. And what's striking, Maria, both Hillary Clinton and Joe Biden have pledged to nominate justices to reverse that decision. And that's, in a very real sense, how our free speech rights are hanging in the balance at the court, one vote away.

BARTIROMO: Wow. Unbelievable.

All right, you mentioned Hillary Clinton. I want to take a break. But when we come back, I've got to ask you about this new declassified document that we got from John Ratcliffe yesterday that basically says it was Hillary Clinton's idea to insert Donald Trump into a story about Russia collusion.

CRUZ: Yes.

BARTIROMO: We'll talk about this when we come right back with you, Senator.

Stay with us. We're talking with Senator Ted Cruz.

We've got breaking news next up.

Then we've got an exclusive report on China. House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy and Texas Congressman Michael McCaul are here to tell us about that exclusive report on their -- from their China task force. It's a "First on Fox" interview. Don't miss it.

Dagen McDowell and Mark Penn are here all morning long. They are weighing in. You'll hear from them coming up as well.

You're watching MORNINGS WITH MARIA live on Fox Business.

Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: I'm back with Senator Ted Cruz this morning.

And we have breaking news, something that I first reported years ago, now it is backed up by bombshell new Crossfire Hurricane documents. They were declassified by Director of National Intelligence John Ratcliffe. Ratcliffe outlined in a letter to Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Lindsey Graham that Hillary Clinton approved a plan to link then candidate Donald Trump to Vladimir Putin and Russian hacking of the DNC. The letter also says that the Obama administration was briefed on this as well.

I broke this story while talking with Senator Graham on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES" yesterday, but now we have the actual documents declassified.

Senator Ted Cruz, what's your reaction to this?

CRUZ: Look, it's a stunning revelation and anyone watching this develop, it's not at the end of the day surprising because it was clear this was a political hit job. This was a political hit job from the beginning. One of the very worst legacies of the Obama/Biden administration is they politicized -- and they did -- they did an awful lot to destroy the Department of Justice and the FBI and the intelligence agencies. And they basically turned DOJ and the FBI into oppo research centers and political attack dogs.

And, in this instance, what was declassified is that Hillary Clinton was personally briefed in July of 2016. So in the middle of the presidential election, she was briefed on a plan, on a scheme, let's accuse Trump of essentially Russia collusion and Hillary, according to the declassified information, she personally signed off on that attack. And then Obama was briefed on it and the Department of Justice began executing that attack.

It -- it -- that's not the job of DOJ and the FBI. And the political leadership at those agencies have a lot to answer for. I hope they're held accountable for their abuse of power because it did enormous damage to the integrity of the institution.

BARTIROMO: It certainly did, Senator. And we've been talking about this for a few years.

On Sunday, I broke news that we are not going to get an interim report from John Durham. It is unlikely that we're going to see any indictments before the election. Perhaps after the election John Durham will tell us some of his conclusions to his criminal investigation into exactly that.

Do you believe we will see indictments? Will we see accountability for this group of leaders at the top of the FBI, and possibly the CIA, who turned our intelligence agencies into weapons against a political opponent?

CRUZ: I don't know. I am frustrated, deeply frustrated that people haven't been held accountable yet. I can tell you, when I'm back in Texas, I hear from Texans all the time that just -- just say, what -- what the hell is wrong? Like, they can break the law, they can abuse power and they seem to get off scot free.

James Comey is going to be testifying before the Judiciary Committee today. I hope that testimony starts to hold him accountable. But I'll tell you, all of these individuals right now seem to be -- there seems to be no consequences for a gross abuse of power.

By the way, when the Obama/Biden administration targeted General Michael Flynn, who had spent decades serving our country honorably defending this nation and they went after him, they attacked him, it was Barack Obama and Joe Biden personally who were directing much of that attack, briefed on it in the Oval Office, both of them, and yet I'm very disappointed if there's going to be no transparency and no accountability before the election. I think that's the Department of Justice not acting swiftly enough to clean up their own mess and to clean up their own department.

And if Joe Biden wins, it will get swept under the rug and no one will ever be held accountable. Part of the reason they need to act with some expediency is one of the principle objectives. I mean, it was -- Joe Biden was implicated directly in this conduct. So if he comes in, covering it up, sweeping it under the rug, ignoring the lawyer at the FBI who fraudulently altered a document and lied to the FISA court, all of that's going to be on the agenda.

BARTIROMO: You're right. You're 100 percent right, Senator. I've been saying this for a long time, Mark Penn. And even though you worked with Hillary Clinton, Mark, you saw this as well. Over the last several years, with me on-set, you knew that there was something that stunk to high heaven here. Your reaction to all of this?

MARK PENN, FORMER SENIOR ADVISOR TO CLINTONS: Well, Senator, I don't see how you can say there were no consequences. You get a book contract. You get speaking fees. You get -- you know, look, I think we know a lot more of the facts for -- this time when Comey comes before to the Senate to testify, right? Previously we didn't know about the White House meeting. Did -- did, in fact, Joe Biden talk about the Logan Act? What happened at that meeting? Did, in fact, the FBI director bypass the Justice Department and give this information to the political appointees and not the Justice Department? Did he lie about when he knew that the Hillary Clinton campaign had paid for the dossier and about the sub source? We know so much more now that this questioning ought to be a lot more difficult for Comey. If it's not, then the people running the Senate are just not -- not up to it.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but, Senator, before you answer that, isn't this a little bit of a sham because it's a public hearing. I mean, come on, he's just going to say that's confidential, I can't get into it, this is specific to what I've been working on. Are we really going to get information from Comey today when you and your colleagues throw these questions at him, as Mark just laid out?

CRUZ: Look, probably not. Comey is slippery. We've seen Sally Yates before testify. She's very slippery. They're very good at dodging. They don't answer questions. They deflect. It's always somebody else's problem. It's always some -- some other issue.

And one of the challenges -- a public hearing can be useful for shining a light, for helping get -- make some of those facts public. But a legislative hearing lacks the ability to indict someone, to bring criminal proceedings, to have actual legal consequences attached to their misconduct. That's what needs to happen. I expect -- and, unfortunately, Comey's testimony today is going to be via zoom or distance, which makes it even worse because he's -- I expect him to dodge every question. Doesn't mean that we're not going to press and I'm certainly going to press, but it's no substitute for a grand jury and an indictment holding people accountable for breaking the law. That's what needs to happen.

BARTIROMO: Yes, who do you think the mastermind of this all was? Was it Hillary Clinton or somebody else?

CRUZ: From what I've seen, John Brennan was right at the middle of all of this. John Brennan running the Intelligence Agency seems to be pulling an awful lot of the strings. But Comey was right in the middle of it and Hillary an Obama and Biden all personally signed off on it.

BARTIROMO: Uh-huh.

All right, Senator, it's great to see you.

Senator Ted Cruz. Congrats on the book, "One Vote Away."

We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Time for the "Word on Wall Street." Top investors watching your money.

Joining me right now is Belpointe Asset Management Chief Strategist David Nelson, and Portfolio Wealth Advisors President and Chief Investment Officer Lee Munson.

Gentlemen, great to see you this morning. Thanks so much for being here.

First up, futures slipping this morning after a contentious first presidential debate.

Lee, what's your outlook heading into October and November? Do you believe that market sentiment is changing after last night's debate?

LEE MUNSON, PRESIDENT AND CIO, PORTFOLIO WEALTH ADVISORS: I think market sentiment is starting to cement that it's going to be volatile. See, I think the election itself is going to drive the volatility going forward. It's less about who's going to win. I think last night proved to the American public and investors that going into November we're -- we may -- we're probably not going to have an answer on November 3rd and this could get dragged out for weeks and weeks. If that happens, that's what I've been saying for the past, you know, several weeks, I think that that just solidified last night. It's going to be an opportunity for investors to take advantage of that downward volatility. I think I see selloffs. I think there's concerns about tightening financial conditions.

While that might be temporary, that's going to happen between now and the end of the year. It's a phenomenal opportunity for people to start buying that weakness because, ultimately, we're going to -- we're going to move forward.

BARTIROMO: Yes, so you -- you really want to be buying this market then.

Let me ask you about the retail fallout. In the first six months of 2020, 18 major retailers filed for Chapter 11. This year on pace to eclipse 2010's 48 retail bankruptcies in the wake of the great recession, David.

What's your outlook and what does this retail fallout tell us about the economy in the fourth quarter and 2021. Here we are in the final day of the third quarter today.

DAVID NELSON, CHIEF STRATEGIST, BELPOINTE ASSET MANAGEMENT: It's -- it's probably at the tip of the iceberg. You saw the news last night. Disney announced 28,000 layoffs. There are close proximity businesses. And close proximity businesses are going to be challenged, retail, restaurants, transportation. I'm in information based technology, financial services. So we have remote services to get us through that.

But you -- these people need some kind of targeted package at this point and there's a reason, Maria, why -- why the ratings for the House and the Senate are probably the lowest in generations because they're failing in their -- in their -- in their job to bring relief to these people. They should put the partisan politics aside.

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, look at the IPO market. It is on fire. Palantir will go public today, the software and data analytics company from FaceBook co- founder Peter Thiel hitting the New York Stock Exchange later this morning. It is doing a direct listing.

What are you expecting here?

Lee, first to you. I want to get your take, both of you, on the Palantir deal today.

MUNSON: Well, I love it. It's your way to buy big brother. I think -- I think it's the right IPO for the right time. Listen, we have a frothy market. They're not looking to raise money, which I think is always telling. It's also priced a little bit below their 2015 valuation, around $20 billion.

But, again, we have a tech company where the founders have complete control. There's a lot of mystery around it. And we're almost 20 years into it. Let's see how it goes. I'm -- I'm interested in the company, quite frankly.

BARTIROMO: David, would you buy this IPO?

NELSON: I can't, and for the following reason, because they're trying to distance themselves from Silicon Valley. But when it comes to voting rights, they're just like everybody else, the founders, the -- Alexander Karp, Peter Thiel, they're going to have super voting shares. In essence, they can control this company for the rest of their life. They can sell as many shares as they want. They're just like Mark Zuckerberg and others in Silicon Valley in that regard. That's why I won't be buying this company.

BARTIROMO: All the media companies and a lot of the technology companies are just that, you're right, they have super voting control.

David Nelson, Lee Munson, we'll be watching the deal certainly and this market.

Great to see you both. Thank you so much.

Dow Industrials down 169.

A quick break and then an exclusive report on China. House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy and Texas Congressman Michael McCaul are here to bring us the report. It's a "First on Fox" interview and they're up next. It's next.

Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for being here. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, September 30th. A look at markets this morning, 7:31 a.m. on the East Coast. Futures are indicating a decline at the start of trading. But we are off of the lows of the morning in the final trading day of the month and this, of course, the final trading day of the quarter.

Dow Industrials down 168 points right now. The Nasdaq down 64, and the S&P 500 lower by 16.5. This after the debate last night, as well as rising coronavirus cases and stimulus uncertainty causing a down day for markets yesterday and this morning. All three major indices are now on pace to snap a five-month winning streak with the Dow Industrials decline yesterday of 131, the Nasdaq was down 32.

It's been a mixed story. As you see, the markets over the month down between 4 percent and 7 percent for the month of September. In Asia, China's manufacturing purchasing manager's index is out for the month of September. It came in above expectations, 51.5. It is coming from the Communist Party, of course, these numbers, but the Shanghai composite even with that better than expected showing was down overnight by a quarter of a percent.

Meanwhile, House Republicans' China Task Force releasing a new report which addresses the Chinese Communist Party's, quote, maligned global agenda. The report outlines a blueprint for bipartisan actions Congress and the administration can take to address the threat of China. Policy recommendations include providing a safe harbor for Hong Kong refugees, a bilateral free trade agreement with Taiwan, and prioritizing national security.

Joining me right now in a "First on Fox Business" interview is House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy and the chairman of the China Task Force, Congressman Michael McCaul.

Great to see you, gentlemen. Thank you so much for being here.

REP. MICHAEL MCCAUL (R-TX): Thanks, Maria.

REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CA): Thanks for having us on, Maria.

BARTIROMO: So, Congressman McCarthy, we didn't hear a lot of China last night. I'm glad you're releasing this report this morning. Tell us what's most important.

MCCARTHY: You know, we tried to do the task force bipartisan. We tried to do it more than a year ago. And, actually, Nancy Pelosi agreed to it. And right before we announced it, she backed out. This is long before Covid.

And the one thing that we've learned, I think, three major items that come out of this, 60 percent of all the ideas out of here are bipartisan. We need to change our supply chain, not just for medical but every other element of what we deal with within China. We need to innovate when it comes to DOD, especially with AI, something that you have focused a lot on, Maria, in hypersonics (ph) and others. And then we've got to refocus when we look at the Treasury Department. They have a team there for Iran and for North Korea, but they have no team in there especially when it comes to sanctions when it comes to China. You know how much they've been stealing from us.

So the modernization and the preparation that we need, especially after what we've learned from Covid when it came to the supply chain, you should apply that to almost every element that we have within government of how far behind we were and we can't allow China to continue to do that to us in the future.

BARTIROMO: Well, I think that's incredible that we don't have that in Treasury --

MCCARTHY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: When we have specific areas of Treasury focused on Iran, North Korea, but -- but not on China. That -- that makes no sense. I'm so glad that you brought this up in this very important report.

Congressman McCaul --

MCCARTHY: We know we --

BARTIROMO: Yes, go ahead.

MCCARTHY: Well, we just need more mandarin speakers as well. There's so many elements of what we've got -- we were woken up to the real challenge after Covid in the supply chain and looking at every department in government, there's a lot of weaknesses there that China has taken advantage of us of that we really have to open up our eyes and do something much different. And that's what this report really shows the rest of the country.

BARTIROMO: Well, this is a very important report.

Congressman McCaul, let me ask you why it's OK for Joe Biden to dodge questions about China. He dodged all questions relating to his kids when we know that Hunter Biden was on that plane, Air Force Two, and then took money from the Chinese Communist Party.

One issue I think is that China has been very strategic in terms of identifying people that will help them, whether that's in business, in academia or even in Congress.

How come Nancy Pelosi won't allow the Democrats to be part of this task force?

MCCAUL: Well, I think they made a big mistake here. They just want to focus on the president. They don't want to focus on where the virus came from. That's China. We want things to be made in America, not made in China. The virus is made in China. But we want manufacturing and jobs made in the United States of America.

And so what the leader is talking about is supply chain. How can we decouple what's really national security related and bring it back home where it's going to protect our national security, but also provide more manufacturing jobs, be really good for the economy.

I think, you know, the idea that they dodged that question is clear. You know, I prosecuted the Johnnie Chang (ph) case in 1996 where there -- the Chinese director of intelligence was putting money in the Clinton campaign. We know the Chinese are trying -- the Communist Party are trying to influence this election right now in favor of Joe Biden and I think that should be part of this discussion as well.

BARTIROMO: Yes, absolutely. And one of the issues has been the supply chain.

Congressman McCarthy, you had made a commitment to America in terms of creating jobs should you become the speaker and take the majority in the House of Representatives this upcoming November. That commitment to America zeros in on job creation. How long is it going to take to get these 10 million jobs created that you believe you can fire up from moving supply chains back to America?

MCCARTHY: Well, we believe we'll create 10 million new jobs within the next year at the end of it.

But one of the elements of making that happen is exactly this, taking a lot of these recommendations that are inside this China task force because what it will do is bring the jobs back to America. And when we're looking at the supply chain, just simply, we don't make penicillin, we don't make vitamins in America anymore. Think for a point if this was something beyond Covid, if this was a national defense challenge, would we be able to resupply the businesses that we have or are we too coupled with China itself? What we're finding is the answer is, yes. And China has been utilizing us for quite some time.

If you go back to 2011, we have a president of the United States, Barack Obama, praising the rise of China and saying it was positive for America. Well, now we're finding out that is not the case. And so we have to rethink what we are doing. That's why we looked at every single department. There's more than 60 percent of this is actually bipartisan. These can be bills that we can move and pass. One-third of them we've already either passed the House or the Senate.

But you brought a good point up, Maria. Why are the Democrats not helping with this? Why did Nancy Pelosi pull back? I'm not sure what the Communist Party has on the Democrats, but it's pretty powerful.

And we're reading in the paper a lot of FBI reports that China, the sophistication that they have of what they've been able to do to the supply chain, they're now applying that when it comes to the election and they have determined who they want to win this election, Joe Biden.

And it was interesting to me how little he would talk about China or even bring up when he was vice president to allow Hunter Biden to fly with him to get billions of dollars from China. He never said anything that he did - - that Hunter did something wrong or that he would stop him if he was to become president of doing that again.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I mean, you would have thought that China would have taken up more time in the debate last night. There was about 15 minutes spent on the green new deal and the climate.

Real quick, before you go, I'm going to speak with Lee Carter in a moment. She's going to give us the dials and what she took away from the debate last night.

Let me get a quick comment from each of you on what struck you most from the first presidential debate last night.

Kick us off, Kevin McCarthy.

MCCARTHY: Well, the very first thing that struck me the most is that Joe Biden wouldn't answer from the standpoint of who would he appoint to the Supreme Court, a decision that everybody's looking at right now. Why does he not answer that?

And to ignore the idea of what his son has done, to just say it did not happen, that is a real challenge and it's an ethical question about what's going forward.

Now, I'd rather have had a real debate, let people be quiet, let people talk about the issues and the ideas moving forward. But many times too, the things that Joe Biden would say, like, shut up, man, and you're a clown, I don't think that's a place for the stage. And I wish -- I wish the commentator would have come back and not allowed Joe Biden not to answer certain questions.

BARTIROMO: Well, we definitely needed more decorum and statesmanship. I totally agree.

Michael McCaul, what struck you?

MCCAUL: Yes, look, this is the greatest challenge, both militarily and economically in our generation. For my dad it was World War II. Growing up, it was the Cold War, 9/11. This generation, this is the biggest challenge we have, the greatest foreign policy challenge we have. And it was very -- it wasn't even mentioned last night.

And, you know, I hope, in the second debate, there will be more focus on what is -- where are the greatest challenges?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCCAUL: The president of the United States is the commander in chief of the United States military, conducts foreign policy and the Chinese Communist Party is the greatest national security threat to the long-term interest of the United States. It needs to be brought up. It needs to be debated and part of this presidential election.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We also didn't hear anything about Middle Eastern peace, which actually we're seeing for the first time in 40 of years or so.

MCCAUL: Right.

BARTIROMO: But, gentlemen, the conversation continues. Thank you very much for breaking that news on the show with your new China Task Force report.

Kevin McCarthy and Michael McCaul, we will see you soon.

Congressman, thank you.

All of this is in my new book. I hope you will pick it up. Pre-order the book, "The Cost: Trump, China and American Revival." That is coming out next month. And you can pre-order it right now at thecostbook.com.

We'll be right back with Lee Carter.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

President Trump and former Vice President Joe Biden squaring off last night. It was largely a fiery affair with both candidates talking over one another.

Pollster and the president of Maslansky and Partners, Lee Carter, is here with the dials to see how people reacted.

Let's take a look at President Trump talking about the economy.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: You've got to open these states up. It's not fair. You're talking about almost just like being in prison. And you look at what's going on with divorce. Look at what's going on with alcoholism and drugs. It's a very, very sad thing.

And he'll close down the whole country. This guy will close down the whole country and destroy our country.

Our country is coming back incredibly well, setting records at is does it. We don't need somebody to come in and say, let's shut it down.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Lee Carter, walk us through all of this.

LEE CARTER, POLLSTER AND PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY AND PARTNERS: So you can see there Republicans are the red line, independents, yellow, Democrats, the blue line.

This was one of the better moments for the president last night. People really agree, the economy cannot be shut again. So you can see Republicans and independents, both really favorable towards this, Democrats, not surprisingly, very unfavorable. Almost everything the president said last night the Democrats just completely shot down.

But this is very consistent with what we've been hearing for quite some time. The worst message that I tested of Joe Biden so far is when he was interviewed and he said he would shut the economy down again. People do not want that. They want us to stay open. They want us to stay safe. And it's really important, they don't want us to be reckless or careless, but they want to know that the economy's going to be open and they want to know the opportunities are coming back.

The side effects of the economy being shut down are long-lasting and this is something that really, really is important to the American people and the president was smart to address it last night.

BARTIROMO: Dagen.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: Lee, broadly speaking, did this debate change anybody's minds?

LEE: Absolutely not. I think -- you know, usually, there's so much talk about do debates even matter. And absolutely they do when you're talking about a close race. So you'll usually see the polls move 2 to 3 percent after -- after a debate. And that's really about the undecides. We still have between 6 and 9 percent of American voters who are undecided, which is kind of hard to imagine in this climate. So if you can move 2 or 3 percent of them, you can really significantly impact the polls.

What I heard last night from voters was that this didn't change their minds. You saw a third of the voters went for Biden, a third of the voters that I talked to went for Trump and fully a third of the voters said that nobody won. I've never seen that before. I've seen disagreements or 50/50 splits, I mean 5 percent or 10 percent of people who respond saying nobody won. But this was fully a third of folks.

And when you look at independent voters, when I looked at undecided voters, which I also look at last night, you didn't see any movement, you saw them flat line and in many ways turn out. And what that concerns me most about is these people might turn out for the rest and say, you know what, I give up. This is just too ugly, it's too much and I'm not even going to go to the polls because if this is my choice, I don't want any of it.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, that's a good point.

That is what I was thinking last night. I was watching it and thinking, well, this is not going over well, that they're talking over each other. But I don't think it's changing anybody's minds. At this point people made their decision.

How about former Vice President Biden commenting on his role in the Democratic Party. Let's take a look and watch these dials again.

Lee, you'll walk us through it on the other side.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOE BIDEN (D), PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE: And one of the big debates we had, with 23 of my colleagues trying to win the nomination that I won, were saying that Biden wanted to allow people to have private insurance still. They can, they do, they will under my proposal.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: That's not what you've said and it's not what your party has said.

BIDEN: And that is -- that is simply a lie.

TRUMP: Your party doesn't say -- your party wants to go socialist medicine --

BIDEN: That is -- my party is me.

TRUMP: And socialist health care.

BIDEN: Right now I am the Democratic Party.

TRUMP: And they're going to dominate you, Joe, you know that.

BIDEN: I am the Democratic Party right now. The platform of the Democratic Party --

TRUMP: Not according to Harris.

BIDEN: Is what I, in fact, approved of.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Lee, walk us through it.

LEE: So, I think this was a -- this was is a really important moment for Joe Biden. He has largely been defined by President Trump as going to the far left, as pandering to Bernie Sanders, as becoming too progressive, as not being a moderate. He clearly stated last night the buck stops here. I am a Democratic Party and these are my decisions. I am going to be more moderate.

This is really important. And he needs to continue to tell this story because people don't know. Only a third of voters know exactly what Joe Biden is going to do should he become president. They're not sure where he stands on the issues. I'm not sure that last night clarified, but at least this was a start and I think it's a really important starting point for him.

BARTIROMO: Well, he says it, but what is he doing, Lee? He's got a green new deal that's going to cost $2 trillion. That's an AOC plan.

LEE: Yes, it's a really fair point. And I think looking at how Kamala Harris supported that and was, you know -- is another really important distinction. We're going to have to hear more about that during the VP debate because there's a lot of question over, where do they differ and where are they the same. Is Joe Biden going to be the one who's going to be dictating policy or is she. So I think we're going to hear more about that next week.

BARTIROMO: All right, Lee, great to get your insights, as always. Lee Carter.

We are looking at markets next when we come back, down 200 points almost on the Dow Industrials, 183.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Markets are lower this morning, but pulling off of the lows after a contentious debate between President Trump and former Vice President Joe Biden last night.

Take a look. Dow futures down 184, Nasdaq down 73. It is the last trading day of the quarter and of the month. Markets are on pace to snap a five- month winning streak, meanwhile.

One sector that has been real volatile this last month, technology.

Joining me right now is RBC Capital Markets managing director and lead Internet analyst, Mark Mahaney.

Mark, it's great to have you this morning. Thank you so much for joining us.

How do you believe the election impacts tech stocks?

MARK MAHANEY, MANAGING DIRECTOR, RBC CAPITAL MARKETS: We did a report on this about three weeks ago with all of our tech analysts. And we looked at the series of issues that I think the tech industry cares most about. Things like gig economy regulation, big tech, anti-trust issues, China, China trade and technology issues. And on most of them, the differences between the two candidates seemed to be pretty nuanced. Almost surprisingly so. You wouldn't have said that about anti-trust measures historically. But the differences between the two candidates are pretty nuanced. The one big difference that affects all companies is, of course, is the corporate tax rate. That's bearish for big tech, but -- as it would be for -- for all companies. So at the margin, I think what the -- what tech investors would like would be just some sort of certainty about the election. And I don't think they're going to get it.

BARTIROMO: OK. And, you know, it doesn't seem like we're going to get it so far.

Mark, let me ask you where the growth is in technology today. You know, we talk about tech as this -- as if it's this one sector.

MAHANEY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: But it's really not. There are so many subsectors. Where's the growth, Mark?

MAHANEY: Well, there's been some sectors that have been fundamentally -- fortunately or unfortunately, benefit -- that have benefited from the Covid crisis. There's no question about it. Online retail, names like Amazon, we've seen a surge, an acceleration, a material acceleration in online retail growth rates. Anything that has to do with at home entertainment, streaming has benefited. And then digital presence, web presence companies have also benefitted. Those have been winners. Losers side have been anything related to travel, anything related to ride sharing. So there are both winners and losers from this crisis.

BARTIROMO: Mark, it's great to have you. Please come back. Sorry about the abbreviated time.

We'll be right back with Congressman Devin Nunes.

urn:contentItem:5T99-3T41-JBHM-S21H-00000-00Sen. Thune's privacy hearing to feature internet providers, big tech firms as groups unveil principles2018-09-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:22ZLexisNexisSen. Thune's privacy hearing to feature internet providers, big tech firms as groups unveil principles

September 13, 2018 | Mariam Baksh Industry witnesses supporting a flexible approach to data security under the rubric of digital privacy will testify at a hearing of the Senate Commerce Committee later this month, which Chairman John Thune (R-SD) has said will inform his efforts to craft national privacy legislation.

"Consumers deserve clear answers and standards on data privacy protection," Thune said Wednesday in a press release announcing the Sept. 26 hearing.

"This hearing will provide leading technology companies and internet service providers an opportunity to explain their approaches to privacy, how they plan to address new requirements from the European Union and California, and what Congress can do to promote clear privacy expectations without hurting innovation," Thune said.

The announcement comes as a number of industry groups have issued "principles" for what national privacy legislation should look like, and as the Federal Trade Commission seeks greater authorities to deter privacy violations, including the ability to craft specific rules for privacy and data security management -- a crucial point for consumer advocates, who say their absence from the hearing's witness list is worrisome.

"A national privacy framework should focus on accomplishing privacy and data security protections," the Internet Association, which represents companies like Google and Facebook, wrote in "privacy principles" the group released Tuesday calling for national privacy legislation. "But laws and regulations should avoid a prescriptive approach to doing so, as such an approach may not be appropriate for all companies and may well become obsolete in light of rapidly developing technology."

The Internet Association and USTelecom, which represents internet service providers, explicitly opposed greater authorities for the FTC in comments submitted to the agency regarding its role in protecting consumers in the digital economy.

Other groups -- BSA-The Software Alliance and the U.S. Chamber of Commerce -- did not directly address the question of greater rulemaking authority for the FTC, in their comments to the agency, but both have now weighed in on how to shape national privacy legislation.

The Chamber called for a flexible approach in its "privacy principles," issued last week, and on Wednesday, BSA-The Software Alliance released a "privacy framework" that said, "Where the processing of data poses risks to the privacy of consumers, privacy frameworks should implement a risk-based approach that tailors protections to circumstances that are likely to lead to substantial harm."

Witnesses set to testify at the Commerce hearing include representatives from USTelecom members AT&T and Charter Communications; Internet Association members Twitter, Google and Amazon; and Apple, which is a member of BSA-The Software Alliance.

"If you are asking how to regulate about privacy, then it's one-sided to only hear from the industry, which has a monetary interest," Allie Bohm, policy counsel for the digital rights advocacy group Public Knowledge told Inside Cybersecurity Wednesday. "I don't want to belittle that interest, it's legitimate to want to have light-touch regulation, but certainly an effort to protect consumers should involve entities that don't have a financial stake at play."

Bohm didn't entirely dismiss the possibility of coming to a consensus, having read the various industry principles.

"I'm very nervous about legislation becoming obsolete if there isn't one place that has that [rulemaking] ability," she said, noting the need to adapt to rapid changes in technology.

She added, "there are places where I see common ground, but the devil's in the details."

One of those areas may include increasing resources for the FTC.

BSA's privacy framework notes that organizations should employ "reasonable and appropriate security measures" and that the FTC "should have the tools and resources necessary to carry out its mission effectively. -- Mariam Baksh (mbaksh@iwpnews.com)

urn:contentItem:5VNW-52S1-DY37-D29H-00000-00Sentiment has shifted on effort against Big Tech;Americans seem quite receptive to plans to break up monopolies2019-03-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:22ZLexisNexisB,BPg. 14Sentiment has shifted on effort against Big TechAmericans seem quite receptive to plans to break up monopoliesDavid StreitfeldNew York Times

SAN FRANCISCO - A decade ago, when the greed and carelessness of the financial industry came close to destroying the U.S. economy, the overwhelming response by politicians and the public was: Meh. Almost instantly, all was forgiven and forgotten.

Now the tech industry - which, among other impressive innovations, provides the world's knowledge on demand, lets people freely broadcast their diverse opinions and has made shopping as easy as pushing a button - has made some mistakes of its own. It has abused privacy, squeezed the competition and casually spread hate. And that's just the beginning of the list.

Google, Facebook, Amazon and Apple might not get away as cleanly as Goldman Sachs and Citigroup. Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., who is seeking the Democratic presidential nomination, released proposals this month that would force tech breakups and impose severe restrictions on what remained. Another Democratic presidential candidate, Sen. Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota, covered more briefly some of the same ground, saying, "We have a major monopoly problem."

At a moment when nearly everything in America seems wildly contentious, antitrust action against tech is getting a sober look. Antitrust is the nuclear bomb of regulatory policy, but the reaction to Warren's and Klobuchar's ideas was surprisingly receptive.

"We've got to break these guys apart," Warren said in an interview on "Face the Nation." The show could name only one critic of her proposal: Howard Schultz, the Starbucks mogul, who is flirting with an independent run for president to the deep disregard of voters.

"A billionaire, right?" Warren noted.

For decades, a politician who mentioned "antitrust" was essentially arguing for more government oversight, which has been dangerous territory at least since the Ronald Reagan administration. "Antitrust" was relegated to the shelf with "socialism" and "wealth inequality" and "higher taxes for higher incomes."

It didn't help that what could be called "maximum antitrust" - when the Justice Department decides a company is abusing its monopoly power and should be broken up - has a mixed history. The government dropped such a case against IBM in 1982 after more than a decade. It settled its case against Microsoft in 2001. Only AT&T, which agreed in 1982 to dissolve itself into a long-distance company and the seven Baby Bells, could be considered an unqualified success from the government's point of view.

The political landscape is shifting, however, at a speed that dumbfounds even antitrust experts. President Barack Obama thought of the tech companies in the way they think of themselves: as progressive, smart entrepreneurs who want what's best for America. His administration declined to pursue Google on antitrust charges and hired from the tech industry for top posts. Top staff members later went to work for the tech industry in top posts, too. It was a cozy relationship.

"Something has definitely changed," said Geoffrey A. Manne, founder of the International Center for Law and Economics, a think tank in Portland, Ore. "Most voters are very fond of Amazon, Apple, Google and even Facebook. But I think there's also a growing sense of skepticism about all these companies. The shine has come off."

Manne, who has been a critic of the antitrust arguments against Google and has received funding from the search giant as well as from some of its competitors, including Comcast and AT&T, eviscerated Warren's proposal with his colleague Alec Stapp in a recent blog post.

They wrote that the senator's plan to turn the top companies into heavily regulated "platform utilities" would make them as resistant to improvement as sewer systems or Amtrak.

And yet, Manne conceded in an interview, increased regulation is an idea whose time may have come.

"There is a long history in America - just not a recent one - of using the power of the state to counteract the economic power of private enterprise," he said. "We may be at that moment again."

The financial firms were predatory last decade, exploiting weak spots in the mortgage markets in a way that undermined their viability. Google and Facebook, by contrast, offer their services for free, while Amazon built its reputation on selling as cheaply as possible.

That makes it hard to regulate them by the antitrust consensus, which for a couple of decades has held that there is no injury unless consumers suffer by paying higher prices.

Nothing is ever really free, of course, and there has been a dawning realization among some consumers that they are paying for these services with information about themselves. How most users feel about this seems up in the air, as evidenced by a SurveyMonkey poll done for the news site Axios.

The headline finding was that "a growing majority now views our online privacy as a crisis." But deeper in the survey was the revelation that more than half the respondents said they were unwilling to pay to keep from being tracked by a service they were using. Twenty-one percent said they would pay less than $1 a month, and no more, for the right.

Users, it seems, want it both ways: privacy and free services. This is the contradiction at the heart of the internet.

Daniel Crane, an antitrust expert at the University of Michigan, said Warren's proposal might be a hard sell to voters. "The median consumer probably feels that she gets lots of free goodies from Big Tech and will worry about what it would mean to go after them," he said.

But Crane noted that being broken up was the least of the companies' worries. "A likelier consequence is that the next acquisition they want to make will be rejected," he said.

That is already happening. One of the anti-competitive complaints about Amazon is that it prohibited its merchants from selling more cheaply elsewhere. That prevented a new platform from underselling Amazon and gaining a competitive edge.
